revision.text:
{{About|[[Central Business District]] of [[Jakarta]]|other uses|Golden Triangle (disambiguation)}} '''Golden Triangle of Jakarta''' ({{lang-id|Segitiga Emas Jakarta}}) is roughly a triangular shape area of [[Jakarta]], [[Indonesia]], which extends from [[Central Jakarta]] to [[South Jakarta]]. Most of the business, financial, and diplomatic establishments are located in the area, which also forms the center of the city. The area is the main [[Central business district|CBD]] of Jakarta, where most of the tallest skyscrapers are located.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://properti.kompas.com/read/2014/04/23/0641557/Segitiga.Emas.Jakarta.Tetap.Primadona|title=Segitiga Emas Jakarta Tetap Primadona|newspaper=Kompas|accessdate=2017-08-10}}</ref> The area is bordered by main avenues of Jakarta, [[Jalan M.H. Thamrin|Thamrin Avenue]]-[[Jalan Jenderal Sudirman|Sudirman Boulevard]] (North-Southwest), [[Jalan H.R. Rasuna Said|Rasuna Said Avenue]] (North-Southeast), and [[Jalan Jenderal Gatot Subroto|Gatot Subroto Avenue]] (East-West). There are many other roads criss-crossing the area. There are clusters of commercial buildings such as [[SCBD]] (45 hectares), [[Setiabudi, South Jakarta|Mega Kuningan]] (54 hectares), Rasuna Epicentrum (53.6 hectares) and Kuningan Persada (17 hectares).<ref>{{cite news|url=https://finance.detik.com/properti/1762054/segitiga-emas-jakarta-tetap-jadi-patokan-kawasan-perkantoran|title=Segitiga Emas Jakarta Tetap Jadi Patokan Kawasan Perkantoran|newspaper=Detik|accessdate=2017-06-20}}</ref> Golden triangle is one of the fastest evolving [[Central Business District|CBD]] in Asia-Pacific region.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.jllrealviews.com/trends/fastest-evolving-central-business-districts-in-asia-pacific/|title=Where are the fastest evolving Central Business Districts in Asia Pacific?|accessdate=2017-06-20}}</ref>
==History and geography == [[File:Sudirman Road 01.jpg|thumb|250px|right|[[Jalan Jenderal Sudirman|Sudirman Avenue]]]] [[File:Thamrin_Road_02.jpg|thumb|250px|right|[[Jalan M.H. Thamrin|Thamrin Road]]]] During the period between 1960-1965 Jakarta's urban development changed drastically when President [[Sukarno]], also an architect and an urban planner, personally drove the city into a modern capital that would not only be the pride of the Indonesian nation, but would also be a "beacon" of a powerful new nation.{{sfn|Silver|2007|p=101}}<ref>[http://www.thejakartapost.com/news/2015/06/22/sukarno-s-vision-a-modern-capital.html Sukarno's vision of a modern capital] www.thejakartapost.com</ref> Development axis of Jakarta was shifted towards south direction starting from [[Medan Merdeka]] to [[Kebayoran Baru|Kebayoran]] as the center of Jakarta in the 1950s, replacing that of [[Medan Merdeka]]-[[Senen]]-[[Salemba]]-[[Jatinegara]] axis which has grown since the 18th century.
Some of the notable infrastructure projects of Sukarno during the first half of the 1960s were, construction of wide avenues like [[Jalan M.H. Thamrin]], [[Jalan Jenderal Sudirman]], [[Jalan Jenderal Gatot Subroto|Jalan Gatot Subroto]] and Semanggi "clover-leaf" highway interchange. [[Jalan H.R. Rasuna Said]] was being developed in 1970's, which after completion along with Sudirman, and Gatot Subroto roads formed the "golden triangle" of Jakarta. During the period, the earliest signs of building appeared in [[Jalan Jenderal Sudirman|Sudirman Road]] north of [[Semanggi Interchange]].{{sfn|Merrillees|2015|p=27}} The concept of golden triangle has long been formed, at least began to be known in the era of the 1990s.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://finance.detik.com/properti/1762054/segitiga-emas-jakarta-tetap-jadi-patokan-kawasan-perkantoran|title=Segitiga Emas Jakarta Tetap Jadi Patokan Kawasan Perkantoran|newspaper=Detik|accessdate=18 August 2017}}</ref> Three points of the triangle which formed the area are, *[[Patung Pemuda Membangun|Youth statue]] in [[Kebayoran Baru, South Jakarta]] *[[:id:Patung Arjuna Wijaya|Arjuna statue]] in [[Merdeka Square, Jakarta|Merdeka Square]], [[Central Jakarta]] *[[:id:Patung Dirgantara|Dirgantara statue]] in [[Pancoran, South Jakarta]] The golden triangle area of Jakarta includes major roads such as Thamrin, Sudirman, Gatot Subroto, Rasuna Said and Mas Mansyur and Satrio. Administratively the Golden Triangle area is located in [[Menteng]], [[Tanah Abang]], [[Setiabudi, South Jakarta|Setiabudi]], [[Kebayoran Baru]] and [[Mampang Prapatan]] sub-district of Jakarta.
==Important areas within Golden Triangle==
[[File:Jalan Gatot Subroto 3.jpg|thumb|right|[[Jalan Jenderal Gatot Subroto|Gatot Subroto Avenue]], which runs east-west of Golden Triangle]] Many commercial centers are developed gradually as clusters within Golden Triangle area, such as [[Selamat Datang Monument|Hotel Indonesia roundabout]], [[SCBD]], [[Setiabudi, South Jakarta|Mega Kuningan]]. Most of the skyscrapers of Jakarta are located within this triangle.
*Many commercial, shopping and hotels are located in and around [[Selamat Datang Monument|Hotel Indonesia roundabout]], such as [[Grand Indonesia]], [[Plaza Indonesia]], [[Thamrin Nine]], [[Hotel Indonesia]], [[Wisma Nusantara]], [[Menara BCA]]. Embassy of [[Japan]], [[Germany]], and [[France]] are situated on [[Jalan M.H. Thamrin]], close to the roundabout. [[Bank Indonesia]] headquarter and first high-rise building of Jakarta [[Sarinah]] also located at [[Jalan M.H. Thamrin]]. *Numerous high-rise building and skyscrapers are located along [[Jalan Jenderal Sudirman|Sudirman Avenue]], such as [[Wisma 46]], [[Menara Astra]], [[Sinarmas MSIG Tower]], [[International Financial Center Jakarta]], [[World Trade Center Jakarta]], [[Sahid Sudirman Center]]. *[[SCBD]] is a mixed development cluster of 45 hectares located at [[Jalan Jenderal Sudirman]]. The area has many commercial skyscraper, shopping and entertainment center. [[District 8 Jakarta|District 8]], [[Pacific Place Jakarta]], [[Indonesia Stock Exchange]], [[The Energy]], [[PCPD Tower]], [[Sequis Center Tower]], [[Equity Tower]] located within the district. As of June, 2017 the 2nd tallest building in Indonesia, [[Treasury Tower]] is located in the district at present. [[Jakarta Signature Tower]], which is under construction, once completed this will be the tallest building in the city and 5th tallest building in the world, is also located in the district.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.thejakartapost.com/news/2012/01/11/scbd-get-world-s-5th-tallest-building.html|title=SCBD to get world’s 5th tallest building|newspaper=The Jakarta Post|accessdate=2017-06-28}}</ref> *Legislative seat of Indonesia [[DPR/MPR Building]] located in between [[Jalan Jenderal Sudirman]] and [[Jalan Jenderal Gatot Subroto]]. [[Gelora Bung Karno Sports Complex]], [[Jakarta Convention Center|JCC]], [[Plaza Senayan]], [[Senayan City]], [[FX Sudirman]], [[Jakarta Regional Metropolitan Police|Jakarta Metropolitan Police Headquarter]] located in and around [[Senayan, Kebayoran Baru|Senayan]] area of Golden Triangle. *Tallest building of Jakarta [[Gama Tower]] located at [[Jalan H.R. Rasuna Said|Rasuna Said Road]]. Foreign embassies of [[Australia]], [[Malaysia]], [[Singapore]], [[Russia]], [[Poland]], [[Netherlands]], [[Switzerland]], [[Hungary]], [[Bosnia and Herzegovina]], [[Turkey]], [[Algeria]], [[Bangladesh]], and [[India]] are located at this road. *[[Setiabudi, South Jakarta|Mega Kuningan]] is a densely concentrated district of high rise buildings with a land area of about 55 hectares. Important buildings in the area are [[World Capital Tower]], [[BTPN Towers]], [[JW Marriott Jakarta]], [[The Ritz-Carlton Hotel Company|Ritz-Carlton Hotel]], [[Ciputra World Jakarta]] complex etc. *''Rasuna Epicentrum'' is an area of 53.6 hectares, consisting of residential, offices, hotels, hospitals, places of worship, sports, shopping and entertainment and education in one area. *[[Jalan Jenderal Gatot Subroto|Gatot Subroto Avenue]] runs east-west direction within Golden Triangle. It is now going through a transformation of building new skyscrapers.[[Capital Place Office Tower|Four Seasons Hotel Tower]], [[Telkom Landmark Complex]], [[The Tower Jakarta|The Tower]], [[Mangkuluhur City]] located in this road.
==Transportation== [[File:Jl Rasuna Said 2.jpg|thumb|300px|right|[[TransJakarta]] bus station at the junction of [[Jalan Jenderal Gatot Subroto|Gatot Subroto Avenue]] & [[Jalan H.R. Rasuna Said|Rasuna Said Road]], on the background skyline of [[Setiabudi, South Jakarta|Mega Kuningan]] ]] The area is served by [[TransJakarta]] [[TransJakarta Corridors|Corridor 1]], [[TransJakarta Corridors|Corridor 6]], [[TransJakarta Corridors|Corridor 9]]. There are many routes operated by [[Kopaja]], [[:id:Mayasari Bakti|Mayasari Bakti]] and [[:id:Pengangkutan Penumpang Djakarta|APTB]] buses. [[Sudirman railway station|Sudirman]], [[Cikini railway station|Cikini]] and [[Gondangdia railway station|Gondangdia]] station of [[KRL Jabodetabek|Jakarta commuter rail]] located within the area. The area will have multiple station of [[Jakarta MRT|MRT]] and [[Jakarta LRT|LRT]].

{{Healthcare in the United States}}
'''Health Reimbursement Account''' is a notional derivative of a '''Health Reimbursement Arrangement''' ('''HRA'''),<ref>[https://www.irs.gov/pub/irs-pdf/p969.pdf IRS Publication 969]</ref> a type of US employer-funded health benefit plan that reimburses employees for out-of-pocket medical expenses. Following implementation of the [[Affordable Care Act]], the health plans must be integrated with a qualified employer-sponsored group health insurance plan to avoid excise tax penalties.<ref>[https://www.irs.gov/pub/irs-drop/n-13-54.pdf IRS Notice 2013-54]</ref> Using a Health Reimbursement Arrangement yields "tax advantages to offset health care costs" for both employees and employers.<ref name=IRS969>Internal Revenue Service. [https://www.irs.gov/pub/irs-pdf/p969.pdf.] 2012.</ref>
==Establishment== Health Reimbursement Accounts are funded solely by the employer; they cannot be funded through employee salary deductions. The employer sets the parameters for the Health Reimbursement Accounts, and unused dollars remain with the employer: they do not follow the employee to new employment.
==Contributions== Health Reimbursement Accounts are notional accounts; no funds are expensed until reimbursements are paid. By health reimbursement arrangements, employers reimburse employees directly only after the employees incur approved medical expenses. According to the IRS, an HRA "must be funded solely by an employer. Contributions cannot be paid through a salary reduction agreement (such as a [[cafeteria plan]]).<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.irs.gov/publications/p969/index.html|title=Publication 969 - Main Content |publisher=IRS|accessdate=22 September 2012}}</ref> There is no minimum or maximum contribution limit on the employer's contributions to an HRA.<ref name=IRS969/>
==Distributions== According to the IRS, employees are reimbursed tax-free for qualified medical expenses up to a maximum amount for a coverage period. HRAs reimburse only items (co-pays, coinsurance, deductibles, and services) agreed to by the employer that are not covered by the employer's selected standard insurance plan (any health insurance plan, not only a [[High Deductible Health Plan]]). The arrangements are described in IRC Section 105.
With an HRA, employers fund individual reimbursement accounts for their employees and define what those funds can be used for, specified out-of-pocket expenses such as deductibles and co-pays.
Qualified claims must be described in the HRA plan document at inception: before reimbursing employees for the medical expenses. Arrangements (medical services, dental services, co-pays, coinsurance, deductibles, participation) may vary from plan to plan, and an employer may have multiple plans in place, allowing much flexibility. The kinds of expenses that can be paid under an HRA are generally the same as the expenses that can be paid through a Flexible Spending Account (FSA).<ref>{{cite web|last=Pfeifer|first=William|title=How to Deduct Medical Bills as Business Expenses at your Law Firm|url=http://law.about.com/od/financialmanagement/a/How-To-Deduct-Medical-Bills-As-Business-Expenses-At-Your-Law-Firm.htm|work=About.com Law Practice Management|publisher=About.com|accessdate=23 January 2012}}</ref>
The employer is not required to prepay into a fund for reimbursements. Instead, the employer reimburses employee claims as they occur.
Reimbursements under an HRA can be made to the following persons: # Current and former employees. # Spouses and dependents of those employees. # Any person the employee could have claimed as a dependent on the employee's return unless: ## The person filed a joint return, ## The person had gross income of $3,400 or more, or ## The employee or spouse, if filing jointly, could be claimed as a dependent on someone else's tax return. # Spouses and dependents of deceased employees.
==Advantages==
Advantages of HRAs for employers include: * Reimbursements of qualified claims are tax-deductible for the employer. * Employers know their maximum expense related to their health care benefit.
Advantages of HRAs for employees include: * Contributions that employers make can be excluded from employees' gross income (contributions must be made by the employer, not come from payroll reductions). * Reimbursements may be tax free if the employee pays qualified medical expenses. * Unused funds in the HRA can be rolled into future years for reimbursement. * HRAs may be offered in conjunction with other employer-provided health benefits, including [[Flexible spending account|Flexible Spending Accounts]] (FSAs). * Employees can be reimbursed for a health care plan that meets their or their families' specific needs, as opposed to a standard company plan.
==Disadvantages== A frequent complaint regarding HRA arrangements is that they are extremely opaque in regards to their requirements. HRAs must follow "a variety of statutory rules and provisions" including the [[Consolidated Omnibus Budget Reconciliation Act of 1985|COBRA]] continuation coverage requirements, [[ERISA]], and [[HIPAA]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Health Reimbursement Arrangements|url=https://www.irs.gov/pub/irs-drop/n-02-45.pdf|publisher=IRS}}</ref>
HRA plans are considered "Primary Payers" subject to Medicare Secondary Payer (MSP) mandatory reporting requirements. There are significant penalties for failure to comply with the MSP reporting requirements. Although the MSP reporting requirements began to apply to certain group health plans on January 1, 2009, [[Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services|CMS]] has delayed mandatory reporting for HRAs.<ref>Employee Benefits Institute of America 7/7/2009</ref>
Rules pertaining to their reimbursements are perceived by member participants to be somewhat contradictory and/or even incoherent, leading some to lose contributions intended for healthcare but later (after the procedure or laboratory test) to be disallowed.
Other disadvantages of HRAs include: * Self-employed persons are usually ineligible. * "Highly compensated" participants may be subject to "certain limitations."
A sole proprietor can employ a spouse who actually helps the business. The employer would need to establish a W-2 to make the spouse's employment legitimate. The health care can be run through the business and save the family, on average, $3,000 each year. As small businesses look to reduce costs, especially medical, the HRA can be a great tool that has been used by all too few since the 1954 tax law.
HRAs are treated as group health plans and subject to the Medicare secondary payment (MSP). HRAs are subject to the provisions regardless of whether or not they have an end-of-year carry-over feature.
Standalone HRAs not offered in conjunction with a High Deductible Health Plan are subjected to restrictions starting in 2014.<ref>http://www.jaeckle.com/Publications/Alerts/StandAloneHRAMayViolatetheHealthCareReformLaw</ref> The law now essentially bans the existence of most such HRAs, as a health plan with maximum benefit limit.

{{Infobox Officeholder |name = Hugh Farley |office = Member of the [[New York Senate]] from the 49th District |term_start = January 1, 2013 |term_end = December 31, 2016 |predecessor = [[David J. Valesky]] |successor = [[Jim Tedisco]] |office2 = Member of the [[New York Senate]] from the 44th District |term_start2 = January 1, 1977 |term_end2 = December 31, 2012 |predecessor2 = [[Fred Isabella]] |successor2 = [[Neil Breslin]] |image = |imagesize = |birth_date = {{birth date and age|1932|11|26}} |birth_place = [[New York City, New York]] |death_date = |death_place = |party = [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] |spouse = Sharon Farley |children = 3 |alma_mater = [[University of Albany]] {{small|B.S.}}
[[American University]] |website = [https://www.nysenate.gov/senators/hugh-t-farley Official website] |religion = }} '''Hugh T. Farley''' (born November 26, 1932) is an [[United States|American]] lawyer, schoolteacher, professor and [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] politician from [[Schenectady County, New York|Schenectady County]], [[New York (state)|New York]]. He served as a member of the [[New York Senate]] from 1977 until he retired in 2017. ==Early life== Farley was born and raised in [[New York City]], [[Indian Lake, New York]], and [[Watertown, New York]]. He is the fifth of six boys. Farley served in the U.S. Army and then was a high school teacher in [[Syracuse, New York]] and [[Maryland]]. Prior to attending college, he also worked as a lineman for the New York Central Railroad.{{cite web |url=https://www.nysenate.gov/senators/hugh-t-farley/about |title=About Hugh T. Farley |accessdate=2016-05-16 }} Hugh Farley holds a [[Juris Doctorate]] from [[Washington College of Law|American University School of Law]], as well as a [[Bachelor of Science]] from the [[SUNY Albany]]. He is also a graduate of [[Mohawk Valley Community College]]. In 1965, he became a member of the faculty at the School of Business of the [[SUNY Albany]], and since 2000, has been Professor Emeritus of Business Law at the college.{{cite web |url=https://www.nysenate.gov/senators/hugh-t-farley/about |title=About Hugh T. Farley |accessdate=2016-05-16 }} Farley, and his wife Sharon have been married for over 55 years and have three children. ==Career== Farley was a member of [[New York State Senate]] for 40 years, beginning in 1977, representing parts of Schenectady and Saratoga Counties, and [[Herkimer County, New York|Herkimer]], [[Hamilton County, New York|Hamilton]], and Counties. In 1979, Farley was chosen as the first Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Aging. As chairman, Farley authored laws creating New York's [[hospice care]] system and a law prohibiting mandatory medical intervention/treatment for [[terminal illness|terminally ill]] patients. In 1989, Farley was appointed to the Chairmanship of the Senate Committee on Banks. In this capacity, he has authored or sponsored numerous laws dealing with banking regulations, including a law enacted in 1994 aimed at making New York's [[interest rate]] [[deregulation]] laws permanent. Farley was a member of the Governor's Commission on Libraries, and an elected delegate to the [[White House]]'s Conference on Libraries in both 1979 and 1991. He is also Chair of the State Senate's Select Committee on Libraries, and in that role he has become known as a national leader and advocate for libraries and reading programs. Farley voted against same-sex marriage legislation on December 2, 2009; and the bill was defeated. After announcing his intention to vote against a same-sex marriage bill before the Senate, his opponent in the 2010 election, Democrat Susan Savage, denounced Farley's position at a rally on the steps of the New York State Capitol.{{cite news |url=http://blog.timesunion.com/capitol/archives/33671/susan-savage-pretty-angry-in-pink/ |title=Susan Savage, pretty angry in pink |work=Times Union |date=2010-10-28 |accessdate=2016-05-16 }} Farley defeated Savage was again re-elected with one of the largest pluralities in the state.{{cite news |url=http://www.dailygazette.com/news/2010/nov/03/1103_farley/ |title=Farley defeats Savage to win 18th term (with video) |work=The Daily Gazette |date=2010-11-03 |accessdate=2016-05-16 }} In 2011, the New York State Legislature enacted a law legalizing same-sex marriage, with Senator Farley again voting no, citing that most of his constituents had expressed opposition to the measure. In 2016, Farley announced that he would not seek re-election in 2016.{{cite news |url=http://www.capitalnewyork.com/article/albany/2016/05/8598220/after-40-years-hugh-farley-announces-decision-leave-senate |title=After 40 years, Hugh Farley announces decision to leave Senate |work=POLITICO New York |date=2016-05-03 |accessdate=2016-05-16 }} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.nysenate.gov/senator/hugh-t-farley New York State Senate: Hugh T. Farley] *[http://www.nysenate.gov/senator/Hugh-t-farley/bio Official Biography of Senator Hugh Farley] *[http://www.fourthbranchofamerica.com/interview_with_hugh_farley.shtml Fourth Branch of America - New York State Senator Hugh Farley] *[http://www.vote-smart.org/issue_rating_category.php?can_id=BS022178&type=category&category=Gun%20Issues Project Vote Smart: Interest Group Ratings] {{s-start}} {{s-par|us-ny-sen}} {{succession box | title = [[New York State Senate]]
44th District | before = [[Fred Isabella]] | years = 1977–2012 | after = [[Neil Breslin]]}} {{s-bef|before=[[David J. Valesky]]}} {{s-ttl|title=[[New York State Senate]]

{{Use mdy dates|date=October 2013}} {{Infobox person | image = Huntington Hartford.jpg | caption = Hartford in 1968 | birth_name = George Huntington Hartford II | birth_date = {{birth date|1911|04|18}} | birth_place = [[New York City]], U.S. | death_date = {{death date and age|2008|05|19|1911|04|18}} | death_place = [[Lyford Cay]], Bahamas | resting_place = Lakeview Memorial Gardens & Mausoleums | education = [[St. Paul's School (Concord, New Hampshire)|St. Paul's School]] | alma_mater = [[Harvard University]] | occupation = Heir to the [[Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company]] fortune, philanthropist and businessman | spouse = {{marriage|Mary Lee Epling|1931|1939|reason=divorced}}
{{marriage|Marjorie Steele|1949|1960|reason=divorced}}
{{marriage|Diane Brown|1962|1970|reason=divorced}}
{{marriage|Elaine Kay|1975|1981|reason=divorced}} | parents = [[Edward V. Hartford]]
Henrietta Guerard Pollitzer | children = 4 | relatives = {{Plainlist| * [[George Huntington Hartford]] (grandfather) * [[George Ludlum Hartford]] (uncle) * [[John Augustine Hartford]] (uncle) }} | website = {{URL|http://www.huntingtonhartford.com/}} }} '''George Huntington Hartford II''' (April 18, 1911 – May 19, 2008) was an American businessman, philanthropist, stage and film producer, and art collector. He was also heir to the [[The Great Atlantic & Pacific Tea Company|A&P]] supermarket fortune. After his father's death in 1922, Hartford became one of the heirs to the estate left by his grandfather and namesake, [[George Huntington Hartford]].Marc Levinson (2011), The Great A&P and the Struggle for Small Business in America, Hill and Wang. {{ISBN|978-0-8090-9543-8}}, p. 88 After graduating from [[Harvard University]] in 1934, he only briefly worked for A&P. For the rest of his life, Hartford focused on numerous other business and charitable enterprises. He owned [[Paradise Island]]{{cite news|url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,939906,00.html|title=The Rich: The Benefactor|date=March 1962 | work=Time}} in [[the Bahamas]], and had numerous other business and real estate interests over his lifetime including [[Tosco Corporation|the Oil Shale Corporation (TOSCO)]],{{cite news|url=https://select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=FA0F12F73A5C147493C2AB178CD85F4C8685F9|title=HARTFORD PLANNING OIL SHALE LAWSUIT | work=The New York Times | date=July 20, 1968}} which he founded in 1955. Hartford was once known as one of the world's richest people.{{cite news|url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,1808636,00.html|title=Milestones|date= May 22, 2008|work=[[Time Magazine]]|first=Alex|last=Altman}}{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2008/05/19/AR2008051902520.html|title=Huntington Hartford lost millions on investments and forays into the arts as a patron, ultimately declaring bankruptcy while living in New York. |date=May 20, 2008|work=[[Washington Post]]|first=Adam|last=Bernstein}} His final years were spent living in the Bahamas with his daughter, Juliet. ==Early life and education== Huntington Hartford was born in [[New York City]], the son of Henrietta Guerard (Pollitzer) and [[Edward V. Hartford]] (1870–1922). He was named George Huntington Hartford II for his grandfather, [[George Huntington Hartford]]. His father and uncles, [[John Augustine Hartford]] and [[George Ludlum Hartford]], privately owned the [[Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company|A&P]] Supermarket, which at one point had 16,000 stores in the U.S. and was the largest retail empire in the world.Marc Levinson (2011), The Great A&P and the Struggle for Small Business in America. Hill and Wang. {{ISBN|978-0-8090-9543-8}}. In the 1950s A&P was the world's largest grocer and, next to General Motors, it sold more goods than any other company in the world. ''Time'' magazine reported that A&P had sales of $2.7 billion in 1950.{{cite news|url=http://www.time.com/time/covers/0,16641,19501113,00.html|title=Time Magazine Cover showing Hartford's uncles|date=November 13, 1950|work=[[Time Magazine]]|accessdate=May 4, 2010}} His maternal grandfather was from an Austrian Jewish family, and his maternal grandmother, who was Protestant, had deep roots in South Carolina.{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=548eAQAAMAAJ&q=%22Flush%20with%20success,%20Edward%20Hartford%20married%20in%20JUNE%201991%201902%20a%20woman%20with%20social%20ambitions%20that%20exceeded%20his%20own:%20Henrietta%20Guerard%20Pollitzer%22&dq=%22Flush%20with%20success,%20Edward%20Hartford%20married%20in%20JUNE%201991%201902%20a%20woman%20with%20social%20ambitions%20that%20exceeded%20his%20own:%20Henrietta%20Guerard%20Pollitzer%22&hl=en&sa=X&ei=nUIQVfuUI4SqyQSru4LIBw&ved=0CBwQ6AEwAA|title=The Connoisseur|date=May 1, 1991|publisher=National Magazine Company|via=Google Books}} Hartford's father was a successful inventor and manufacturer who perfected the automotive [[shock absorber]]. Along with his brothers, Edward was also an heir to the A&P fortune and served as A&P's corporate secretary as well as one of three trustees that controlled A&P's stock. After Hartford's birth, the family moved to [[Deal, New Jersey]], a wealthy community on the Atlantic shore.{{cite news |first=Daniel |last=Lewis |coauthors= |title= Huntington Hartford, A&P Heir, Dies at 97|work=New York Times |page= |date=May 20, 2008|accessdate= |quote= |url=}} After Huntington's father died when he was 11, his mother moved the family to a mansion in [[Newport, Rhode Island]] known as "Seaverge" next to [[Rough Point]], the mansion owned by tobacco heiress [[Doris Duke]]. The family also lived on a {{convert|1000|acre|km2|adj=on}} plantation in [[South Carolina]] called "Wando" as well as an apartment on Fifth Avenue in [[Manhattan]].{{cite web|url=http://mrsastor.com/2008_05_01_archive.htm |title=Mrs. Astor and the Gilded Age |publisher= |date=May 23, 2008 |accessdate=December 26, 2011 }}{{dead link|date=April 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} After his father died in 1922, Hartford's mother sent him to [[St. Paul's School (Concord, New Hampshire)|St. Paul's School]]. He later majored in English literature at [[Harvard University]]. After his graduation from Harvard in 1934, he went to work at A&P headquarters in New York in the statistical department. He lived on a trust fund that generated about $1.5 million per year. On 10 November 1936, he purchased from Alan Villiers the sailing ship [[Joseph Conrad (ship)|Joseph Conrad]]{{cite book|last1=Villiers|first1=Alan|title=Cruise of the Conrad|date=1937|publisher=Charles Scribner's Sons|pages=379|url=http://opac.navalmarinearchive.com/cgi-bin/koha/opac-detail.pl?biblionumber=11414}} which he converted to a private yacht, and donated to the [[U.S. Maritime Commission]] as a sail training ship in 1939. ==Career== In 1940, Hartford invested $100,000 to help start a newspaper, ''PM'', with [[Marshall Field III]] and worked as a reporter for the publication. An avid sailor, he donated his [[yacht]] to the [[United States Coast Guard|Coast Guard]] at the start of [[World War II]]. During the war he was commissioned in the Coast Guard and commanded the Army supply ship ''FS-179'', commissioned in May 1944, in the Pacific Theater. Hartford twice accidentally ran the ship aground.https://www.nytimes.com/2008/05/20/arts/design/20hartford.html After the war, he moved to Los Angeles and attempted to purchase [[Republic Pictures]] and [[RKO Studios]] from [[Howard Hughes]]. Huntington also started a modeling agency and an artists' colony, and opened a theater. In the 1950s, Hartford purchased a penthouse duplex on the 13th and 14th floors of [[Beekman Place (Manhattan)|One Beekman Place]] in the 1950s after moving from an apartment at the River House in New York City. He owned a home called "Pompano" on 240 El Vedado Drive in [[Palm Beach, Florida|Palm Beach]], a {{convert|150|acre|km2|adj=on}} estate in [[Mahwah, New Jersey]] called "Melody Farm", a {{convert|160|acre|km2|adj=on}} Hollywood estate known as "The Pines" (also known as [[Runyon Canyon Park]]), a townhouse in London, a home in [[Juan-les-Pins]] France and a house on [[Paradise Island]] in the [[Bahamas]].{{cite news|url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,939906,00.html|title=The Benefactor|date=March 2, 1962|work=[[Time Magazine]] | accessdate=May 4, 2010}} Hartford owned Huntington Hartford Productions which produced several films including the [[Abbott and Costello]] film, ''[[Africa Screams]]'', in 1949. In 1950, Hartford produced ''[[Hello Out There]]'', the last film of [[James Whale]], the acclaimed director of the [[Frankenstein (1931 film)|1931 version of ''Frankenstein'']]. He produced several films starring Marjorie Steele and encouraged her to become an artist. In 1955, Hartford founded the Oil Shale Corporation, later known as Tosco, and was its majority shareholder and chairman. Tosco was later acquired by [[ConocoPhillips]]. He also set up the Denver Research Institute at the [[University of Denver]] to find alternate methods of oil extraction. During this period, he also wrote and produced ''The Master of Thornfield'', a stage adaptation of ''[[Jane Eyre]]'' that ran for two weeks in Cincinnati starring [[Errol Flynn]] as Mr. Rochester. This partnership led to Flynn staying in Hartford's pool-house briefly in 1957–58 and is the origin of a legend that "The Pines" was Flynn's estate. Later, Hartford produced the play on Broadway. In 1964, Hartford offered The Pines as a gift to the city but was turned down by Mayor [[Sam Yorty]]. As Lloyd Wright recalled in 1977, "Here was this very wealthy man, and he wanted to give something very stunning to Hollywood. The Chambers of Commerce, the hotel owners and the various businesses were jealous of the park and with the help of the city officials, the city refused to give us permits. Hunt was so angry that he wanted to get out immediately and sold the property to [Jules] Berman who destroyed the mansion and let the place run down."{{cite quote|date=November 2014}} When his uncle George Ludlum Hartford died in 1957, the trust set up by the elder George Huntington Hartford was liquidated and Hartford inherited his portion of the estate. The ''[[Chicago Tribune]]'' estimated his wealth in 1969 as half a billion dollars.{{cite news|url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/chicagotribune/access/583423642.html?dids=583423642:583423642&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:AI&type=historic&date=Mar+09%2C+1969&author=&pub=Chicago+Tribune&desc=Huntingon+Hartford+Is+Really+One+of+the+Good+Guys&pqatl=google|title=Huntingon Hartford Is Really One of the Good Guys|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=March 9, 1969|accessdate=January 1, 2012}} In 1959, [[Mike Wallace]] introduced him on television interview as being worth half a billion dollars.{{cite news|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=JwR8Z4L_ccg|title=Mike Wallace interviews A&P Supermarket Heir Huntington Hartford|work=[[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]]|date=May 12, 1959|accessdate=December 27, 2011}} [[Image:Frenchcloisters.jpg|thumb|left|14th-century French cloisters reassembled by Hartford on Paradise Island]] In 1959, Hartford bought Hog Island in the Bahamas, renaming it [[Paradise Island]]. He developed it over the next three years hoping to turn it into another [[Monte Carlo]]. One feature of his Ocean Club was a cloister built from the disassembled stones of a monastery that [[William Randolph Hearst]] had stored in a Florida warehouse. In an interview with [[David Frost]] on British television, Hartford stated that the flag he created for Paradise Island was in the shape of a "P" and that he wanted to put it on the moon as a symbol of peace for the world.{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1511987|title=The David Frost Show|work=[[IMDB]]}} Hartford was responsible for getting the gambling license for Paradise Island by hiring Sir [[Stafford Sands]], a Bahamian lawyer. In 1969, Hartford produced the Broadway show ''[[Does a Tiger Wear a Necktie?]]'', which opened at the [[Belasco Theater]] starring the then-unknown actor [[Al Pacino]]. Pacino won a [[Tony Award|Tony]] for his performance.{{cite news|url=https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000199/bio|title=Al Pacino biography|work=[[IMDB]]|accessdate=January 4, 2011}} ===Patronage of the arts=== [[Image:2 Columbus Circle.jpg|thumb|upright|Huntington Hartford funded the Gallery of Modern Art at 2 Columbus Circle]] Hartford was a patron of the arts, building an artists colony above Los Angeles and later a gallery in New York City, and his opinions on the arts were equally strong. He criticized Abstract Expressionists, believing they had ushered in a great "ice age of art," freezing out the grand traditions of music, painting and sculpture; he described [[Pablo Picasso]] as a "mountebank".Sam Watters, [http://www.latimes.com/features/la-hm-lostla10-2009jan10,0,2361475.story Colony in Pacific Palisades nurtured top artists in 1950s, 1960s], ''Los Angeles Times'', January 10, 2009, accessed August 19, 2013. Beyond expressionism, he derided the "[[beatnik]], the [[Existentialist]], the juvenile delinquent, the zaniest of abstract art, the weirdest aberrations of the mentally unbalanced, the do-nothing philosophy of [[Zen Buddhism]]" as a result of wanton "abuse of liberty and freedom." He had strong opinions against the work of [[Tennessee Williams]], [[T. S. Eliot]], and [[Willem de Kooning]], as well as art dealer [[Sidney Janis]]. To support the art that he enjoyed, Hartford built an artists' colony in [[Rustic Canyon, Los Angeles|Rustic Canyon]], above the [[Pacific Palisades, Los Angeles|Pacific Palisades]] neighborhood of Los Angeles. Buying more than 150 acres in 1948, he hired [[Lloyd Wright]] (son of [[Frank Lloyd Wright]]) to adapt existing structures and design new ones. When it opened in 1951, it had more than a dozen cottages and a central dining room for distinguished artists, composers and craftspeople who won scholarships for one to six-month retreats. For nearly 15 years, more than 400 colony artists generated international success with exhibitions, concerts, theater performances and [[Pulitzer Prize]]s; included among them were composers [[Ernst Toch]] and [[Ruth Shaw Wylie]], writer and activist [[Max Eastman]], and painter [[Edward Hopper]]. Hartford also renovated and opened a theater which he renamed the [[Huntington Hartford Theater]], which opened in 1954. For ten years the Hartford Theater was Los Angeles's premier venue for Broadway-scale productions featuring the stars of the time.{{cite web |url=http://www.themontalban.com/history-of-our-theater/ |title=History of Our Theatre |publisher=Ricardo Montalbán Theatre |accessdate=February 25, 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170305171704/http://www.themontalban.com/history-of-our-theater/ |archive-date=March 5, 2017 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }} Hartford's taste for Los Angeles began to wane, however, after the [[Los Angeles County Museum of Art]] rejected an exhibition he proposed. He decided to build his own museum in New York City, the 1964 Gallery of Modern Art on New York's Columbus Circle, declaring that building a museum in Los Angeles was like putting up "a theater in [[Oklahoma]]" due to a lack of audience. With the financial commitment to a new museum in New York and tiring of his art colony, he asked local government officials and wealthy patrons to contribute to the colony's support. Lacking what he felt would be sufficient commitment, he shut down the colony in 1965 (he had sold the Huntington Hartford Theater in 1964).{{cite web |url=http://cinematreasures.org/theaters/9863 |title=Ricardo Montalban Theater |work=Cinema Treasures |accessdate=February 25, 2017}} ===Art collection=== Hartford owned an extensive art collection. In an interview by [[Edward R. Murrow]] on his show ''[[Person to Person]]'' he gave a tour of the collection at his Beekman Place apartment including [[Rembrandt]]'s "Portrait of a man, half-length, with his arms akimbo", which sold at [[Christie's]] auction house in London on December 8, 2009 for $33 million, a world record for a Rembrandt.{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2009/sep/18/rembrandt-portrait-sale|title=Rembrandt for sale|work=[[The Guardian]]|date=September 18, 2009|first=Maeve|last=Kennedy|accessdate=May 4, 2010|location=London}} To house his extensive collection of 19th- and 20th-century art, Hartford built the Gallery of Modern Art at [[2 Columbus Circle]] in Manhattan which opened in 1964. Pointedly, it did not include [[Abstract Expressionism]] which Hartford panned in his book, ''Art or Anarchy''. Hartford was a patron of the architect [[Edward Durell Stone]] who designed the modernist marble-clad structure often derided as the "lollipop building". Stone had previously designed the [[Museum of Modern Art]] for the [[Rockefeller]] family. Hartford commissioned [[Salvador Dalí]] to paint [[The Discovery of America by Christopher Columbus]] for the museum's opening. The museum also included Hartford's paintings by [[Monet]], [[Manet]], [[Degas]], and [[Henri de Toulouse-Lautrec]]. Hartford closed the museum after five years. Later the building housed the New York City Department of Cultural Affairs and was recently rebuilt with a new facade to house the [[Museum of Arts and Design]]. ==Personal life== Hartford was married four times, all ending in divorce, and had five children. His mother intended Huntington to marry [[Doris Duke]], but in April 1931, Huntington married Mary Lee Epling, the 18-year-old daughter of a dentist from Covington, West Virginia. They divorced in 1939. In 1938, Huntington had a son, Edward "Buzzy" Barton, with dancer Mary Barton.{{cite web|url=http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/news/topstories/2008-05-19-3416697470_x.htm|title=A&P heir Huntington Hartford dies at age 97|last=Melia|first=Michael|date=May 19, 2008|publisher=usatoday.com|accessdate=November 14, 2014}} Hartford supported the boy financially but refused to legally acknowledge him as his son. In 1967, Edward Barton died of a self-inflicted gunshot wound to the head.{{cite web|url=http://www.vanityfair.com/culture/features/2004/12/hartford200412#|title=Hostage of Fortune|last=Andrews|first=Suzanna|date=December 2004|publisher=vanityfair.com|page=3|accessdate=November 14, 2014}} Huntington's second wife was Marjorie Steele, an aspiring actress whom Hartford married in 1949. The couple had two children, Catherine (born 1950) and John Hartford (born 1958). The couple divorced in 1960. Catherine Hartford died of a drug overdose in June 1988.{{cite web|url=http://www.glamourgirlsofthesilverscreen.com/show/123/Huntington+Hartford/index.html|title=The Life and Times of Huntington Hartford|publisher=glamourgirlsofthesilverscreen.com|accessdate=November 14, 2014}} John Hartford later became a musician and music teacher. He died of [[throat cancer]] on April 15, 2011.{{cite web|url=http://www.newmilfordspectrum.com/news/article/John-Hartford-57-enjoyed-teaching-music-1345665.php|title=John Hartford, 57, enjoyed teaching music|date=April 20, 2011|publisher=newmilfordspectrum.com|accessdate=November 14, 2014}} In 1962, Hartford married Diane Brown at Melody Farm in [[Mahwah, New Jersey]]. They had a daughter, Cynara Juliet, before divorcing in 1970. Five years later, he married Elaine Kay but was divorced again in 1981.{{cite journal|last=Diliberto|first=Gioia|date=June 9, 1986|title=Huntington Hartford's Third Wife, Diane, Claims Her Ex Is Bedrugged, Bedeviled and Bewildered by Unsavory Friends|journal=People|volume=25|issue=23|issn=0093-7673|url=http://www.people.com/people/archive/article/0,,20093833,00.html}} ==Later years and death== In February 2004, he and his daughter moved to [[Lyford Cay]] in the Bahamas.{{cite web|url=http://www.vanityfair.com/culture/features/2004/12/hartford200412#|title=Hostage of Fortune|last=Andrews|first=Suzanna|date=December 2004|publisher=vanityfair.com|page=4|accessdate=November 14, 2014}} Hartford died at his home in Lyford Cay on May 19, 2008 at the age of 97. The cause of his death was publicly released.{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2008/05/19/AR2008051902520.html|title=Huntington Hartford II; A& P Heir Lost Millions On Cultural Investments|last=Bernstein|first=Adam|date=May 20, 2008|publisher=washingtonpost.com|accessdate=November 14, 2014}} His remains are interred at Lakeview Memorial Gardens & Mausoleums in [[Nassau, Bahamas|Nassau]]. ==In popular culture== * Hartford was portrayed by [[John McMartin]] in the 2004 film ''[[Kinsey (film)|Kinsey]]'', directed by [[Bill Condon]]. * Hartford's Ocean Club, situated on Paradise Island, was featured in two [[James Bond]] films: ''[[Thunderball (film)|Thunderball]]'', in 1965, and ''[[Casino Royale (2006 film)|Casino Royale]]'' in 2006. His then-wife, Diane Brown, has a cameo in ''Thunderball'' as the woman James Bond ([[Sean Connery]]) briefly dances with at the ''"Kiss Kiss"'' Club in Nassau.{{citation needed|date=November 2018}} {{unreferenced|date=September 2010}} {{Infobox Governor |name = James Emilius Broome |image = Florida Governor James E. Broome.jpg |order = 3rd |office = Governor of Florida |term_start = October 3, 1853 |term_end = October 5, 1857 |lieutenant = |predecessor = [[Thomas Brown (Florida politician)|Thomas Brown]] |successor = [[Madison S. Perry]] |birth_date = December 15, 1808 |birth_place = [[Hamburg, Aiken County, South Carolina]] |death_date = {{death date and age|1883|11|23|1808|12|15}} |death_place = [[DeLand, Florida]] |party = [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic]] |spouse =Amelia Ann Dozier
Martha (Hawkins) Macon
Henrietta Ann Scott
Adelia Kinnier |profession = |religion = }} '''James Emilius Broome''' (December 15, 1808 – November 23, 1883) was an American politician who was the [[List of Governors of Florida|third Governor]] of Florida. == Early life and career == Broome was born in [[Hamburg, Aiken County, South Carolina|Hamburg, South Carolina]] and moved to Florida in 1837. He engaged in the mercantile business until he retired in 1841. In that same year, Governor [[Richard Keith Call]] appointed him to the position of [[Probate|Probate Judge]] of [[Leon County, Florida|Leon County]]. He served in that position until 1848. == Political life == He was elected governor in 1852 as a [[United States Democratic Party|Democrat]], and took office on October 3, 1853. He was an early [[States' rights|States'-Righter]]. During his term, the [[United States Whig Party|Whig Party]], the opposition to the [[United States Democratic Party|Democrats]] at the time, controlled the [[Florida State Legislature]]. He vetoed so many of the bills that were passed by the legislature that he became known as the "Veto Governor". After his gubernatorial stint ended on October 5, 1857, Broome served as a member of the [[Florida Senate]] in 1861. A large [[Planter (American South)|planter]], he was very sympathetic to the [[Confederate States of America|Confederate]] cause. == Marriages == James E. Broome was married five times. In 1865, he moved to New York City. On a visit with his son in [[DeLand, Florida]], Broome died in 1883. ==External links== *[http://dhr.dos.state.fl.us/museum/collections/governors/about.cfm?id=10 Official Governor's portrait and biography from the State of Florida] *{{fg|34377899}} {{s-start}} {{s-off}} {{succession box|title=[[List of Governors of Florida|Governor of Florida]]|before=[[Thomas Brown (Florida politician)|Thomas Brown]]|after=[[Madison S. Perry]]|years=October 3, 1853 – October 5, 1857}} {{s-end}} {{Governors of Florida}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Broome, James E.}} [[Category:Governors of Florida]] [[Category:Florida Democrats]] [[Category:1808 births]] [[Category:1883 deaths]] [[Category:Democratic Party state governors of the United States]] [[Category:People from Hamburg, South Carolina]] [[Category:People from Leon County, Florida]] [[Category:19th-century American politicians]] [[Category:American planters]] [[Category:American slave owners]] [[Category:American businesspeople]] [[Category:American merchants]] [[Category:19th-century American judges]] [[Category:Whig Party (United States) politicians]] [[Category:People from New York City]] [[Category:States' rights]] {{Florida-politician-stub}}

|November 18, 1878|1893|reason=her death}}

|1914|1927|reason=his death}} | children = [[Tadd Roosevelt]]
Helen Rebecca Roosevelt | parents = [[James Roosevelt I]]

[[Caroline Webster Schermerhorn Astor]] (mother-in-law) | box_width = }} '''James Roosevelt "Rosy" Roosevelt''' (April 27, 1854 – May 7, 1927) was an American diplomat, heir, and the older half-brother of [[List of Presidents of the United States|32nd President]] of the United States [[Franklin D. Roosevelt|Franklin Delano Roosevelt]]. ==Early life== James Roosevelt Roosevelt was born on April 27, 1854.[http://wc.rootsweb.ancestry.com/cgi-bin/igm.cgi?op=GET&db=roosevelt&id=I123 Roosevelt – Claes Martensen of New Amsterdam–New York City] He was the son of [[James Roosevelt I]] (1828–1900) and his first wife, Rebecca Brien Howland (1831–1876), who were second cousins.{{cite book|last1=Whittelsey|first1=Charles Barney|title=The Roosevelt Genealogy, 1649-1902|date=1902|publisher=Press of J.B. Burr & Company|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=8W1BAAAAYAAJ&printsec=frontcover&dq=Roosevelt+Genealogy#v=onepage&q=Roosevelt%20Genealogy&f=false|accessdate=21 June 2017|language=en}} He was described as "an aimless if charming member of New York society's sporting set." by the ''[[The New York Times|New York Times]]''.Ware, Susan. [https://www.nytimes.com/1985/07/14/books/hyde-park-bucolic.html "Hyde Park Bucolic"] ''[[The New York Times]]'' (July 14, 1985). Review of Ward, Geoffrey C. ''Feore the Trumpet Young Franklin Roosevelt: 1882-1905'' (New York: Harper & Row, 1985) When his father died in 1900, the estate was split between Rosy and Franklin Delano Roosevelt. ==Career== Roosevelt served as Secretary of the United States Legation in [[Vienna]] and as Secretary of the Embassy in [[London]]. He was a trustee of the [[Cathedral of Saint John the Divine]] and was a close friend of [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York|Cardinal]] [[Patrick Joseph Hayes]]. He donated more than $250,000 to [[St. Francis Hospital (New York City)|St. Francis Hospital]] in New York and also to gave substantial funds to the parish of [[St. James Episcopal Church (Hyde Park, New York)|St. James Episcopal Church]] in Hyde Park. ==Personal life== On November 18, 1878, Rosy married Helen Schermerhorn Astor (1855–1893), the second daughter of businessman [[William Backhouse Astor Jr.|William Astor Jr.]] (1829–1892) and socialite [[Caroline Webster Schermerhorn Astor|Caroline Webster Schermerhorn]] (1830–1908).{{cite news|title=A Notable Social Event; The Wedding of Miss Astor and Mr. Roosevelt; An English Morning Ceremony in Grace Church the Recpetion in the Astor Mansion; The Bride's Presents and Some of the Costumes.|url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9D00E5D9153EE63BBC4152DFB7678383669FDE&legacy=true|accessdate=21 June 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=19 November 1878}}{{cite news|title=Court Disposes of an Astor Fund.; Provisions as to It in Mrs. Roosevelt's Will Held to be Inoperative.|url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9905E0D71F39E033A25756C2A9639C94659ED7CF&legacy=true|accessdate=21 June 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=25 May 1894}} Together, Roosevelt and Helen had two children: * [[Tadd Roosevelt|James Roosevelt "Tadd" Roosevelt Jr.]] (1879–1958), who married Sadie Messinger (c. 1880–1940) * Helen Rebecca Roosevelt (1881–1962), who in 1904 married [[Theodore Douglas Robinson]] (1883–1934), the eldest nephew of President [[Theodore Roosevelt]] (1858–1919){{cite news|title=Mrs. Theodore Robinson Dies {{!}} Navy Official's Widow Was 80|url=http://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1962/07/10/82053929.html|accessdate=4 October 2016|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=July 10, 1962}} After his first wife's death in 1893, Roosevelt married Elizabeth Riley on August 7, 1914. Roosevelt died on May 7, 1927. His second wife outlived him, and died in 1948.{{cite news|last1=Times|first1=Special to The New York|title=J. R. Roosevelt, 73, Dies at Hyde Park; Philanthropist and Trustee of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine. Victim of Bronchitis – Brother-in-Law of Late Col. J. J. Astor and Half Brother of Franklin D. Roosevelt.|url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9A01E2D9123FE03ABC4053DFB366838C639EDE&legacy=true|accessdate=21 June 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=8 May 1927}} ==References== ;Notes {{reflist|30em}} ;Sources *Black, Conrad ''Franklin Delano Roosevelt: Champion of Freedom'' (2005) *Miller, Nathan ''Theodore Roosevelt: A Life'' (1992) *Moffat, R. Burnham ''The Barclays of New york: who they are and who they are not,-and some other Barclays'' (1904) ==External links== *[http://www.fdrlibrary.marist.edu:8000/findbrow.cgi?collection=Roosevelt+Family "Roosevelt family papers"] on the FDR Library website *[http://www.fdrlibrary.marist.edu/archives/resources/genealogy.html "FDR Genealogy"] on the FDR Library website *{{Find a Grave|18151512}} *[http://wc.rootsweb.ancestry.com/cgi-bin/igm.cgi?op=GET&db=roosevelt&id=I63 "Helen Rebecca Roosevelt"] on Ancestry.com {{Franklin D. Roosevelt|state=collapsed}} {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Roosevelt, James Roosevelt}} [[Category:1854 births]] [[Category:1927 deaths]] [[Category:American diplomats]] [[Category:American people of Dutch descent]] [[Category:American people of English descent]] [[Category:Astor family]] [[Category:Livingston family]] [[Category:People from New York City]] [[Category:Roosevelt family|James]] {{US-gov-bio-stub}}

Concerts: 21,666{{cite web|title=Arena Info: General Information|url=http://redwings.nhl.com/club/page.htm?id=43887|publisher=The Detroit Red Wings|accessdate=December 8, 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121101013629/http://redwings.nhl.com/club/page.htm?id=43887|archivedate=November 1, 2012|df=}} }} [[File:Joe-Louis-Arena.jpg|thumb|right|250px|Inside Joe Louis Arena.]] [[File:Retired numbers at Joe Louis Arena.jpg|thumb|right|250px|The retired numbers of former Detroit Red Wings players displayed at Joe Louis Arena.]] [[File:JoeLouisArenaPanorama.jpg|thumb|right|250px|Panorama of Joe Louis Arena in April 2008.]] [[File:Hoops in Hockeytown.jpg|thumb|rught|250px|The Detroit Shock practice at Joe Louis Arena before Game 5 of the 2006 WNBA Finals.]] '''Joe Louis Arena''' is a defunct multi-purpose [[arena]] in [[Detroit]], [[Michigan]]. Completed in 1979 at a cost of $57 million as a replacement for the [[Detroit Olympia]], it sits adjacent to [[Cobo Center]] on the bank of the [[Detroit River]] and is accessible by the [[Joe Louis Arena station]] on the [[Detroit People Mover]]. The venue is named after former heavyweight champion [[boxer]] [[Joe Louis]], who grew up in Detroit. It was the home of the [[Detroit Red Wings]] of the [[National Hockey League]] and the second oldest NHL venue after [[Madison Square Garden]] until the start of the [[2017–18 NHL season]]. Joe Louis Arena is owned by the city of Detroit, and operated by [[Olympia Entertainment]], a subsidiary of team owner [[Ilitch Holdings]].{{cite web |url=http://www.olympiaentertainment.com/about-olympia-entertainment|title=About Olympia Entertainment|accessdate=July 2, 2017}} In April 2017, the Red Wings hosted their final game at Joe Louis Arena; the venue was succeeded by the new [[Little Caesars Arena]], in [[Midtown Detroit]], beginning with the 2017–18 season. Joe Louis Arena will be demolished, and its site slated for redevelopment. The arena closed on July 30, 2017. Demolition was scheduled to begin in September 2017, but Olympia renewed the lease of the arena with the city and are using it as storage and offices until November 2017. Olympia Entertainment moved out in November 2017, and demolition is planned to begin sometime in 2019.https://www.freep.com/story/money/business/2018/02/03/demolition-detroit-joe-louis-arena/1088694001/ ==History== Joe Louis Arena replaced the [[Olympia Stadium]], where the [[Detroit Red Wings]] had played since 1927. The neighborhood around the Olympia had gradually deteriorated, especially after the [[1967 Detroit riot]]. After two murders near the Olympia, Red Wings owner [[Bruce Norris (ice hockey)|Bruce Norris]] seriously considered moving to a proposed arena in suburban [[Pontiac, Michigan|Pontiac]]. However, the city of Detroit countered with a proposal for a new riverfront arena at one-third of the rent Pontiac was offering. The package also gave the Red Wings operational control of the arena, nearby [[Cobo Arena]] and nearby lots. The arena hosted its first event on December 12, 1979: a college basketball game between the [[1979–80 Michigan Wolverines men's basketball team|University of Michigan]] and the [[Detroit Titans men's basketball|University of Detroit]].{{citation needed|date=May 2015}} The Red Wings played their first game at Joe Louis Arena on December 27, 1979, hosting the [[St. Louis Blues]]. The game ended in a 3-2 loss for the Red Wings.{{cite news |title=Red Wings Celebrate 30th Anniversary of Joe Louis Arena|first=Ansar|last=Khan|url=http://www.mlive.com/redwings/index.ssf/2009/12/red_wings_celebrate_30th_anniv.html|work=Michigan Live|date=December 26, 2009|accessdate=March 2, 2011}} The Red Wings first win at the arena came on December 30, 1979, where they defeated the [[New York Islanders]] 4-2. {{fact|date=November 2018}} Later that first season it hosted the 32nd [[National Hockey League All-Star Game|NHL All-Star Game]] on February 5, 1980,{{cite web |title=NHL All-Star Game Summaries/Results by Year|url=http://www.nhl.com/ice/page.htm?id=29166|publisher=National Hockey League|accessdate=March 2, 2011}} which was played before a then-NHL record crowd of 21,002. Joe Louis Arena was the site of the [[1987 NHL Entry Draft]], which marked the first NHL Entry Draft to be held in the United States. In 1980, the arena hosted the [[1980 Republican National Convention|Republican National Convention]] that nominated [[Ronald Reagan]] as the Republican candidate for [[President of the United States]]. [[File:New scoreboard.jpg|thumb|250px|right|The electronic scoreboard at Joe Louis Arena, during a game between the [[Detroit Red Wings]] and the [[Los Angeles Kings]] on March 9, 2007]] In 1990, color matrix boards were installed on the scoreboard; these were replaced by four Sony [[JumboTron]] video walls three years later, when the matrix boards were placed in the corners of the fascia. In 2006, LED video screens replaced the JumboTrons. The screens debuted November 22, 2006, when the Red Wings played the [[Vancouver Canucks]]. That same day, the arena's West Entrance was named the "[[Gordie Howe]] Entrance" in honor of the legendary Red Wing player, and a bronze statue of Howe was placed inside the entrance. Joe Louis Arena houses 86 premium suites.{{cite web |url=http://hockey.ballparks.com/NHL/DetroitRedWings/index.htm|title=Joe Louis Arena|work=Ballparks.com|accessdate=March 2, 2011}} In 2008, the arena introduced the Comerica Bank Legend's Club, a 181-person private seating location in the arena's southeast corner.{{cite news |title=Competitive Spirit Makes Mike Ilitch Perfect Fit for Pistons|first=Bob|last=Wojnowski|url=http://detnews.com/article/20100810/OPINION03/8100328/Competitive-spirit-makes-Mike-Ilitch-perfect-fit-for-Pistons|newspaper=[[The Detroit News]]|date=August 10, 2010|accessdate=March 2, 2011}} === Replacement === {{main|Little Caesars Arena}} On July 20, 2014, following the July 2013 approval of a $650 million project to build a new sports and entertainment district in Downtown Detroit,{{cite news |title=$650 Million Detroit Red Wings Arena Project Clears Another Public Financing Hurdle|first=David|last=Muller|url=http://www.mlive.com/business/detroit/index.ssf/2013/07/650_million_detroit_red_wings.html|work=[[Booth Newspapers|MLive]]|date=July 24, 2013|accessdate=July 24, 2013}}{{cite web |title=DDA, Red Wings Unveil $650 Million Arena and Entertainment Complex|first=Bill|last=Shea|url=http://www.crainsdetroit.com/article/20130619/NEWS/130619810/dda-red-wings-unveil-650-million-arena-and-entertainment-complex#|work=Crain's Detroit Business|date=June 19, 2013|accessdate=June 19, 2013}} Christopher Ilitch unveiled designs for a [[Little Caesars Arena|new arena]] near [[Comerica Park]] and [[Ford Field]] which was completed in 2017 and succeeded Joe Louis Arena as the home of the Red Wings.{{cite web|title=Detroit Rink City: Ilitches' grand plan to supersize the entertainment district|url=http://www.crainsdetroit.com/article/20140720/NEWS03/140719845/detroit-rink-city-ilitches-grand-plan-to-supersize-the|website=Crain's Detroit Business|accessdate=September 21, 2014}} On October 16, 2014, lawyers involved in the ongoing [[Detroit bankruptcy]] case disclosed [[United States District Court for the Eastern District of Michigan|in court]] that after demolition (which will be paid for by the city and state), the land on which the arena stands, along with an adjacent parking lot, will be transferred to the [[Financial Guaranty Insurance Company]] (FGIC), a bond insurer with a $1 billion claim against the city.{{cite news|title=Detroit bankruptcy deal: Joe Louis Arena site to go to creditor for hotel development|url=http://www.mlive.com/news/detroit/index.ssf/2014/10/detroit_bankruptcy_deal_joe_lo.html|accessdate=17 October 2014|work=MILive.com|date=16 October 2014}} The Red Wings' final game at Joe Louis Arena was played on April 9, 2017 against the [[New Jersey Devils]]. The Red Wings won 4–1, the final goal in the arena's history coming from Red Wing [[Riley Sheahan]]. It was the second of two he scored, which were also the only goals he scored at all during the 2016–17 season.{{cite web|title=Watch Red Wings' Riley Sheahan end 79-game drought with first goal|url=http://www.mlive.com/redwings/index.ssf/2017/04/watch_red_wings_riley_sheahan.html|website=MLive|accessdate=31 May 2017}}{{cite web|title=What slump? Riley Sheahan scores two goals in Joe Louis Arena finale|url=http://www.freep.com/story/sports/nhl/red-wings/2017/04/09/red-wings-riley-sheahan-goal/100266430/|website=Detroit Free Press|accessdate=31 May 2017}} The last ticketed event held at The Joe was a [[World Wrestling Entertainment|WWE]] Live Event, held on July 29, 2017. The arena will be demolished and replaced with new development at the site in 2019. ==Other tenants and events== In 1995, the [[Detroit Junior Red Wings]] won the [[Ontario Hockey League]]'s [[J. Ross Robertson Cup]], defeating the [[Guelph Storm]]. Joe Louis Arena hosted college hockey events as part of [[College Hockey at The Joe]], the [[Great Lakes Invitational]], and the [[Big Ten Conference]] hockey tournament in 2015 and 2017.{{cite news |title=New Detroit Arena Will Be in Mix to Host Many Events|first=George|last=Sipple|url=http://www.freep.com/story/sports/nhl/red-wings/2014/09/24/detroit-red-wings-arena/16155149/|newspaper=Detroit Free Press|date=September 24, 2014|accessdate=November 18, 2014}} The [[Detroit Pistons]] of the NBA used the arena for Game 5 of [[1984 NBA Playoffs#(4) Detroit Pistons vs. (5) New York Knicks|their 1984 playoff series]] against the [[New York Knicks]] when the [[Pontiac Silverdome]] was unavailable due to a scheduling conflict. In the game, Pistons star [[Isiah Thomas]] scored 16 points in the final 1:34 of regulation to send the game into overtime before the Pistons lost. The Pistons were forced to return to Joe Louis Arena for 15 games during the 1984–85 season, after the roof of the Silverdome collapsed during a snowstorm. The National Hockey League's [[Detroit Red Wings]] hosted the [[Stanley Cup Finals]] at the arena six times (1995, 1997, 1998, 2002, 2008, and 2009), and won two of their Stanley Cup championships at Joe Louis Arena in 1997 and 2002. The 1998 Stanley Cup championship was won in Washington, D.C.'s [[MCI Center]] and the 2008 championship was won in Pittsburgh's [[Mellon Arena]]. The Red Wings lost in the Finals to New Jersey in 1995 at the [[Meadowlands Arena]] and lost on home ice in the 2009 Stanley Cup Finals to Pittsburgh. Joe Louis Arena was the site of the decisive Game 5 of the [[2006 WNBA Finals]] between the [[Sacramento Monarchs]] and [[Detroit Shock]] on September 9, due to [[The Palace of Auburn Hills]] (the Shock's usual home arena) being used for a [[Mariah Carey]] concert on the same day. The Shock won the game 80–75 to clinch the championship. Former [[Arena Football League]] team the [[Detroit Drive]] also had success during their time at the arena, playing in six consecutive ArenaBowls from 1988 to 1993 and winning four of them. Four of the games ([[ArenaBowl III]], [[ArenaBowl IV]], [[ArenaBowl V]] and [[ArenaBowl VII]]) were played in Joe Louis Arena. Joe Louis Arena was the site of the [[2013 Skate America|2013 edition]] of the [[Skate America]] figure skating competition. In addition, Joe Louis Arena hosted the [[1994 U.S. Figure Skating Championships]], best known for the pre-competition attack on [[Nancy Kerrigan]] by associates of [[Tonya Harding]]. It was announced on May 7, 2015, that the [[Horizon League Men's Basketball Tournament]] would be held in Detroit beginning in 2016 under a five-year deal; the 2016 and 2017 tournaments were held at Joe Louis Arena.{{cite web|title=Moving Horizon League tourney to Detroit is all about branding|url=http://www.detroitnews.com/story/sports/college/2015/05/07/jla-to-host-horizon-league-basketball-tournament/70957924/|website=Detroit News|publisher=Digital First Media|accessdate=8 May 2015|date=May 7, 2015}} Joe Louis Arena was also a [[concert]] venue. Until the Palace of Auburn Hills was built in 1988, Joe Louis Arena was Michigan's largest indoor arena for concerts. The first concert to take place there occurred on February 17, 1980,{{Cite web|url =http://www.2112.net/powerwindows/tours/800217ticket.jpg|title =February 17th, 1980 Rush ticket stub|date =|access-date =|website =|publisher =|last =|first =|deadurl =yes|archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20160415110222/http://www.2112.net/powerwindows/tours/800217ticket.jpg|archivedate =2016-04-15|df =}} in which [[Max Webster]] opened for the Canadian rock group [[Rush (band)|Rush]] To compensate for most of Joe Louis Arena's concert business being moved north following the opening of the Palace, the Red Wings began a tradition of playing a home game on [[New Year's Eve]]. Aside from [[Labor unrest|lockouts]] cancelling part or all of the [[1994–95 NHL lockout|1994–95]], [[2004–05 NHL lockout|2004–05]], and [[2012–13 NHL lockout|2012–13]] seasons, the Red Wings left the New Year's Eve date open in years they were scheduled to participate in the [[NHL Winter Classic]]. For New Year's Eve 2012 and 2013, the [[Zac Brown Band]] held concerts at the Joe. The 2012 date was open due to the planned 2013 Winter Classic that was postponed by lockout until [[2014 NHL Winter Classic|2014]]. ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== {{Portal|Metro Detroit}} {{Commons category|Joe Louis Arena}} * [http://www.olympiaentertainment.com/venues/detail/joe-louis-arena Official website] * page.title: John D. Rockefeller Jr. Memorial Parkway

revision.text:
{{Infobox protected area | name = John D. Rockefeller Jr. Memorial Parkway | iucn_category = V <!-- https://www.protectedplanet.net/11111517 ---> | photo = | photo_caption = | map = USA | relief = 1 | map_caption = | location = [[Teton County, Wyoming]], U.S. | nearest_city = [[Jackson, Wyoming]] | coordinates = {{coords|44|6|17|N|110|41|34|W|region:US-WY|display=inline, title}} | area_acre = 24,000 | established = August 25, 1972 | visitation_num = 1,137,117 | visitation_year = 2003 | governing_body = [[National Park Service]] }} '''John D. Rockefeller Jr. Memorial Parkway''' is a scenic road that connects [[Grand Teton National Park]] and [[Yellowstone National Park]] in the U.S. state of [[Wyoming]]. It is federally owned and managed by the [[National Park Service]]. It is named in remembrance of [[John D. Rockefeller Jr.]], a conservationist and philanthropist who was instrumental in the creation and enlargement of numerous [[national parks]] including [[Grand Teton National Park|Grand Teton]], [[Virgin Islands National Park|Virgin Islands]], [[Acadia National Park|Acadia]] and the [[Great Smoky Mountains National Park|Great Smoky Mountains]].
Created in 1972 through the authorization of the [[United States Congress]], and consisting of {{convert|24,000|acre}}, it also borders [[United States National Forest|National Forest]] lands and is an integral part of the [[Greater Yellowstone Ecosystem]]. [[Caribou-Targhee National Forest]] borders the parkway on the west and [[Bridger-Teton National Forest]] and the [[Teton Wilderness]] forms the eastern border. [[File:JDR Parkway.JPG|right|thumb|The [[Snake River]] in [[Wyoming]]]]
The land was originally part of [[Teton National Forest]] and was transferred to the [[National Park Service]] from the United States Forest Service to assure an unbroken connection between Grand Teton and Yellowstone National Parks. The parkway road itself extends from the northern end of Grand Teton National Park, through the parkway lands, and then on to [[Geothermal areas of Yellowstone|West Thumb Geyser Basin]] in Yellowstone National Park, a distance of 27 miles (43 km). The 24,000-acre park is managed by Grand Teton National Park.
The parkway is a transitional zone in terms of [[geology]] with ancient [[lava]] beds being found in the north and the granitic rocks of the Teton Range in the south. The [[Snake River]] flows through the parkway as it heads south to [[Jackson Lake]] and is considered a prime [[trout]] [[fly fishing]] area. In Grand Teton and Yellowstone, [[grizzly bears]], [[American black bear|black bears]], [[moose]], [[Red Deer|elk]], [[bighorn sheep]] and [[mule deer]] can be found there. The [[Yellowstone fires of 1988]] affected the northern sections of the parkway consuming {{convert|4,000|acre}}). As of 2005, the forest had begun to be rejuvenated and wildlife habitat had actually increased due to better mix of meadow and forest lands. A major relocation project for the [[Flagg Ranch]] concession operation (consisting of a lodge, gas station, camp store, cabins and a campground) from along the Snake River to a point higher up and less visible from the road was completed in 2002. Rafting is a popular activity during the summer and guided snowmobile tours use the parkway as a starting point for trips into Yellowstone during the winter.
==See also== [[File:Entrance sign at the John D. Rockefeller Jr. Memorial Parkway.png|right|thumb|Entrance sign]]
* [[Rockefeller family]]
==External links== * {{cite web |publisher=National Park Service |url=https://www.nps.gov/grte/planyourvisit/jodr.htm |title=John D. Rockefeller, Jr. Memorial Parkway |accessdate=2016-05-29}} * {{cite web |publisher=TopoQuest |url=http://www.topoquest.com/map.asp?z=12&n=4882940&e=526616&size=l&u=7&datum=nad83 |title=Snake River Recreation Site (historical), USGS Flagg Ranch (WY) Topo Map |accessdate=2008-06-30}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=January 2016}} {{Infobox person | image = | image_size = | name = Leon Patitsas | caption = | birth_name = Leon Patitsas | birth_date = {{bya|1976|02}} | birth_place = London, England | death_date = | death_place = | death_cause = | restingplace = | nationality = British/Greek | religion = | ethnicity = | residence = | education = Campion High School, [[Moraitis School]] | alma mater = [[Tufts University]], [[MIT]] | occupation = Shipowner | known for = Founder and owner, [[Atlas Maritime]] | salary = | networth = | spouse = [[Marietta Chrousala]] | parents = Spyros Patitsas
Marigo Lemou – Patitsa | relatives = Philimon Patitsas (brother) | website = }} '''Leon Patitsas''' (born February 1976) is a London-born Greek shipowner, founder and owner of [[Atlas Maritime]]. ==Early life== Leon Patitsas was born in February 1976,{{cite web|title=Atlas Maritime.(UK) Ltd|url=https://beta.companieshouse.gov.uk/company/09403880/officers|website=Companies House|accessdate=9 February 2016}} in London, the son of Spyridon (Spyros) Patitsas and Marigo Lemou – Patitsa, who was the daughter of Captain Leon C. Lemos. He has an older brother, Philimon Patitsas.{{cite web|url=http://www.neomagazine.com/2010_11_november/14.html |title=NEO, November 2010 – Leon and Philimon Patitsas of Atlas Maritime: A Success Story built on Professionalism and Ethics |website=Neomagazine.com |date= |accessdate=2015-12-05}} He was educated at [[Moraitis School]], a private school in Athens, followed by a degree in Mechanical Engineering from [[Tufts University]], Boston. and a Master of Science from [[MIT]]. ==Career== Mr. Patitsas founded [[Atlas Maritime]] in 2004.{{cite web|url=http://www.atlasmaritime.eu/board-of-directors |title=Atlas Maritime – Board of Directors |website=Atlasmaritime.eu |date= |accessdate=2015-12-05}} ==Personal life== On 5 June 2010, Patitsas married [[Marietta Chrousala]], a Greek fashion model and television presenter. The 2008 "Posidonia" party took place aboard the [[Greek cruiser Georgios Averof]], a famous war memorial.{{cite web|author= |url=http://keeptalkinggreece.wordpress.com/2010/06/14/what-a-partyscandal-navy-bows-to-money/ |title=What a Party-Scandal! Navy bows to Money (Upds) | Keep Talking Greece |website=Keeptalkinggreece.wordpress.com |date=14 June 2010 |accessdate=2015-12-05}} In 2013, Patitsas bought a loft apartment at New York City for $5.5 million.{{cite web|author=Stephen Jacob Smith |url=http://observer.com/2013/07/greek-shipping-scion-drops-anchor-in-soho/ |title=Greek Shipping Scion Drops Anchor in Soho |publisher=Observer |date=12 July 2013 |accessdate=2015-12-05}} ==References== {{Reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Patitsas, Leon}} [[Category:1976 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Lemos family]] [[Category:Tufts University School of Engineering alumni]] [[Category:Greek businesspeople]]

{{Infobox person | name = Lewis Miller | image =Lewis_Miller-Akron_OH.jpg | image_size = 200px | caption = ''"Life-long supporter of the best interests of American labor and industry." - American Economist (March 3, 1899)'' | birth_name = | birth_date = {{Birth date|1829|12|13}} | birth_place =[[Greentown, Ohio]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|1899|2|17|1829|7|24}} | death_place = [[New York City]], [[New York (state)|New York]] | death_cause = [[Kidney disease]] | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = | nationality = | ethnicity = | citizenship = | other_names = | known_for = Inventor of ''Buckeye Mower'' (1855), ''[[Akron Plan]]'' architecture for Sunday school buildings (1867), co-founder of the [[Chautauqua Institute|Chautauqua Assembly]] (1874), philanthropy | education = [[Subscription school]], Plainfield Academy, learned [[machinist|machinist trade]] in [[Plainfield, Illinois]] and [[Canton, Ohio]] | alma_mater = | employer = C. Aultman & Co.
Aultman, Miller & Co.
Buckeye Mower & Reaper Co. | occupation = Inventor and industrialist | title = Partner, Superintendent, and President (c. 1892) | salary = | networth = | height = | weight = | term = | predecessor = | successor = | party = [[Greenback Party|Greenback]] candidate for [[United States Congress|Congress]] (1878) | boards = | spouse = {{marriage|Mary Valinda Alexander |1852}} | partner = | children = | parents = | relatives = [[Thomas Edison]] (son-in-law)
[[Emily Huntington Miller]] (sister-in-law)
[[Charles Edison]] (grandson)
[[Theodore Miller Edison]] (grandson) | signature = Lewis_Miller_Akron_Sig.png | website = | footnotes = }} '''Lewis Miller''' (July 24, 1829 – February 17, 1899) was an [[Ohio]] businessman and philanthropist who made a fortune in the late 19th century as inventor of the first [[Combine harvester|combine]] (harvester-reaper machine) with the blade mounted efficiently in front of the driver, to the side of the horse(s), rather than pulled behind. His daughter Mina (1865–1947) married fellow Ohio inventor [[Thomas Alva Edison]] on February 24, 1886.{{Cite web|url=https://www.nps.gov/edis/learn/historyculture/mina-miller-edison.htm|title=Mina Miller Edison - Thomas Edison National Historical Park (U.S. National Park Service)|website=www.nps.gov|language=en|access-date=2018-04-25}} ==Biography== Miller was born in [[Greentown, Ohio]]. He devoted much of his wealth to public service and to charitable causes associated with the [[Methodist Episcopal Church]], and was the inventor of the "[[Akron Plan]]" for Sunday schools, a building layout with a central assembly hall surrounded by small classrooms, a configuration Miller conceived with Methodist minister [[John Heyl Vincent]] and architect [[Jacob Snyder]]. The arrangement accommodated 1) a collective opening exercise for all the children; 2) small radiating classrooms for graded instruction in the uniform lesson of the day; and 3) a general closing exercise in the central assembly area. [[John Heyl Vincent]] collaborating was baptist layman B.F. Jacobs devised a system to encourage Sunday school work, and a committee was established to provide the International Uniform Lesson Curriculum, also known as the "Uniform Lesson Plan". By the 1800s, 80% of all new members were introduced to the church through Sunday school."Sunday School Movement”, Dictionary of Christianity in America, InterVarsity Press, 1990, p 1147 In 1874, interested in improving the training of Sunday school teachers for the Uniform Lesson Plan, Miller and Vincent worked together again to found what is now the [[Chautauqua Institution]] on the shores of [[Chautauqua Lake|Chautauqua Lake, New York]]. Miller died in 1899 of [[kidney disease]] and was buried in [[Glendale Cemetery]] in Akron, Ohio.Vigil, Vicki Blum (2007). ''Cemeteries of Northeast Ohio: Stones, Symbols & Stories''. Cleveland, OH: Gray & Company, Publishers. {{ISBN|978-1-59851-025-6}} ==References== ==Further reading== *''New York Times'', February 18, 1899, p12 *''Lewis Miller'' by Ellwood Hendrick, 1925. {{ISBN|1-567-23121-7}}. Book, discusses his farm machinery patents as well as his co-founding of the Chautauqua Institution. *"Theodore W. Miller Rough Rider, his Diary as a soldier together with the story of his life..." by George E Vincent 1899 ==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20070714100912/http://www.invent.org/hall_of_fame/290.html Biography at National Inventors Hall of Fame] * {{Find a Grave|5200465}} * {{Find a Grave|5204203}} * [http://australianscreen.com.au/titles/wheat-harvesting/clip1 1899 film of a ''Buckeye Mower (Reaper)'' harvesting wheat in Queensland Australia] {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Miller, Lewis}} [[Category:1829 births]] [[Category:1899 deaths]] [[Category:American inventors]] [[Category:American Methodists]] [[Category:People from Stark County, Ohio]] [[Category:Chautauqua Institution]] [[Category:American philanthropists]] [[Category:Edison family]] [[Category:Burials at Glendale Cemetery, Akron]]
