{{Infobox officeholder |name = Lina Shabib |office = Minister of Transport |term_start = 21 August 2013 |term_end = |predecessor = |successor = |birth_date = |birth_place = |death_date = |death_place = |party = }} '''Lina Shabib''' is a [[Jordanian people|Jordanian]] politician and government Minister of Transport.<ref>{{cite news|title=Dr. Lina Shabib, Jordan’s Minister of Transport has received Bilal Al Bodour, the UAE Ambassador to Jordan, in her office.|url=http://www.fananews.com/en/uae/271325/|accessdate=23 November 2017|work=fananews.com|language=ar-Jo}}</ref>
==Biography== Lina Shahib was appointed the Minister of Transport of Jordan in the cabinet of Prime Minister [[Abdullah Ensour]] on 21 August 2013.<ref>{{cite news|title=Jordanian PM Announces Cabinet Shuffle Ahead of Elections|url=https://www.al-monitor.com/pulse/ar/politics/2013/08/jordan-pm-ensour-cabinet-shuffle-elections.html|accessdate=23 November 2017|work=Al-Monitor|date=22 August 2013|language=ar}}</ref> She attended the General Assembly of the Arab Bridge Maritime Company in Cairo, Egypt in 31 December 2013, where she discussed ways to improve transport connections with Egypt and Iraq.<ref>{{cite news|title=Jordan discusses transport cooperation with Egypt and Iraq|url=http://jordanembassyus.org/news/jordan-discusses-transport-cooperation-egypt-and-iraq|accessdate=23 November 2017|work=jordanembassyus.org|publisher=Petra News Agency}}</ref> Under her, the transport ministry filed a complaint with the International Civil Aviation Organization against Israel over the construction of [[Ramon Airport]] in [[Timna Valley]] on July 2015. Jordan in the complaint said that the new airport would be to close to its own [[King Hussein International Airport]] in [[Aqaba]] and will disrupt air traffic to the airport.<ref>{{cite news|title=Report: ICAO looking into Jordan complaint against Israeli airport|url=https://www.maannews.com/Content.aspx?id=766631|accessdate=23 November 2017|work=Maan News Agency}}</ref> On 7 May she signed an Memorandum of Understanding with [[Ivaylo Moskovski]], the Bulgarian Minister of Transport, Information Technology and Communications that sought to improve aviation and transport ties between Jordan and Bulgaria.<ref>{{cite news|title=Jordan, Bulgaria Ministries of Transport sign MoU|url=http://www.petra.gov.jo/public_news/Nws_NewsDetails.aspx?Menu_ID=&Site_Id=1&lang=2&NewsID=194868&CatID=13|accessdate=23 November 2017|work=www.petra.gov.jo|agency=Jordan News Agency}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Shabib, Lina}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Government ministers of Jordan]] [[Category:Jordanian women in politics]] [[Category:Jordanian businesspeople]] [[Category:Year of birth missing (living people)]]

{{Infobox software | name = List & Label | screenshot = | caption = | developer = combit | operating system = [[Microsoft Windows]] | language = English, German. Enduser Designer: English, German, French, Czech, Danish, Dutch, Italian, Polish, Portuguese, Russian, Spanish | genre = [[Reporting software]], [[Business Intelligence]] | license = proprietary | website = http://www.combit.com/en/reporting-tool/report-generator-List-Label }} '''List & Label''' is a reporting tool for developers to enable the design and print of reports in [[Microsoft Windows]] applications. It supports data sources and development environments such as [[Microsoft Visual Studio]], [[Embarcadero RAD Studio]]. Reports are designed once in the interactive Designer and can then be exported to formats such as [[PDF]], [[Microsoft Excel|Excel]], [[XHTML]] and [[Rich Text Format|RTF]]. For the custom preview format, a free viewer application is available. The Designer can be used by end-users royalty free with all paid editions of List & Label.
==History== The product was first released in 1992 by combit. The current version is 24, released in October 2018.
==Features==
===Report Designer=== The Designer enables users to graphically layout the report. It offers report objects such as tables, charts, crosstabs, gauges, [[HTML]], formatted text, barcodes, matrix codes, lines, rectangles and images. Object properties can either have a fixed value or a conditional formatting. The Designer can be extended by the developer – custom objects, functions and menu actions are supported. The application can interact with the report via the programmable object model of the report. HTML5 viewer is available.
===Data Sources=== Depending on the programming language, the product offers automatic support for data sources: * Databases such as [[Microsoft SQL Server]], [[Oracle database|Oracle]], [[MySQL]], [[PostgreSQL]], [[IBM DB2]], [[SQLite]] * [[XML]] data * Business objects * Data sources that can be accessed via [[OLE DB]], [[ODBC]] or [[ADO.NET|ADO]] * [[LINQ]] data and data from web services Additionally, the product offers support for unbound data and can be extended to support other [[Data source (disambiguation)|data source]]s via interfaces.<ref>[http://www.combit.net/reporting-tool-en/manual-report-generator-List-Label.pdf List & Label Programmer's reference]</ref>
===Export Formats=== * [[PDF]] * [[XHTML]]/[[MHTML]]/[[HTML]] * [[Microsoft Excel]] * [[Rich Text Format]] * [[Open XML Paper Specification|XPS]] * [[XML]] * [[DOCX]] * [[PPTX]] * [[Plain text]] * Image Formats ([[Portable Network Graphics|PNG]], [[TIFF]], [[Multi-TIFF]], [[JPEG]], [[BMP file format|BMP]], [[SVG]], [[Windows Metafile|EMF]])<ref>[http://www.combit.net/reporting-tool-en/manual-report-generator-List-Label.pdf List & Label Programmer's reference: chapter 6 Export Modules]</ref>
===Target Audience=== List & Label can be used in Windows development environments. While it competes with other products such as [[Crystal Reports]], [[SQL Server Reporting Services]], [[ActiveReports]], and most notably on the [[Microsoft .NET]] platform, there are few competing products for other programming languages (e.g. [[OpenEdge Advanced Business Language|Progress]], [[Alaska Xbase++]], [[Visual DataFlex]]).
==Awards== *Rating: "very good". "List & Label is the most important development tool made in Germany ...", PC Magazin 01/09 *Reader's Choice Award 2008: "Best Component", dotnetpro magazine <ref>[http://it-republik.de/dotnet/sonstiges/readers-choice-2008-72.html Reader's Choice Award 2008: "Best Component", dotnetpro magazine]</ref> *Reader's Choice Award 2008: "Best Reporting-Tool", dot.net magazine *Test result "Top product, Rating: very good", PC Magazin 02/08 *Reader's Choice Award 2007: "Best Component", dotnetpro magazine *Reader's Choice Award 2007: "Best Reporting Tool", Der Entwickler (The Developer) <ref>[http://entwickler-magazin.de/zonen/magazine/psecom,id,43,nodeid,17,p,0.html Reader's Choice Award 2007: "Best Reporting Tool", Der Entwickler (The Developer)]</ref> *Reader's Choice Award 2007: "Best Reporting Tool", dot.net magazine <ref>[http://entwickler.com/itr/service/psecom,id,373,nodeid,37.html Reader's Choice Award 2007: "Best Reporting Tool", dot.net magazine]</ref> *"Final grade: very good; highest rating: 5 out of 5 points", PC Magazin 12/06<ref>[http://www.magnus.de/testbericht/reportgenerator-reporter-ohne-grenzen-90845,6510.html "Final grade: very good; highest rating: 5 out of 5 points", PC Magazin 12/06]</ref> *Reader's Choice Award 2006: "Best Database Tool", dot.net magazine <ref>[http://www.dotnet-magazin.de/itr/service/psecom,id,320,nodeid,37.html Reader's Choice Award 2006: "Best Database Tool", dot.net magazine]</ref> *Reader's Choice Award 2006: "Bestes Reporting-Tool" <ref>[http://entwickler-magazin.de/umfrage/de/2006/index.xhtml Reader's *Choice Award 2006: "Bestes Reporting-Tool"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110718235419/http://entwickler-magazin.de/umfrage/de/2006/index.xhtml |date=2011-07-18 }}</ref> *"Final grade: very good; highest rating: 5 out of 5 points". "Awarded: Top Product List & Label", PC Magazin 10/05 *"Rating: 1.4". "Usability: 1.5 + user friendly report designer". {{Orphan|date=August 2016}}
{{Infobox organization | name = MIT Global Startup Workshop | logo = MIT Global Startup Workshop.jpg | type = Not-for-profit Educational Organization | caption = Dedicated to fostering entrepreneurship and building entrepreneurial ecosystems globally | founded = 1998 | location = [[Cambridge]], [[Massachusetts]], United States | parent_organization = [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology]] | area_served = Worldwide | website = [http://gsw.mit.edu/ gsw.mit.edu] }}
'''MIT Global Startup Workshop (MIT GSW)''' is a flagship event of the [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology]]<ref>{{Cite web|title = The Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT)|url = http://mit.edu/|access-date = 2016-02-14}}</ref> run by a student group in association with [[Martin Trust Center for MIT Entrepreneurship]],<ref>{{Cite web|title = Home {{!}} Martin Trust Center for MIT Entrepreneurship |url = http://entrepreneurship.mit.edu/|access-date = 2016-02-14}}</ref> the MIT Legatum Center for Development and Entrepreneurship,<ref>{{Cite web|title = Home {{!}} MIT Legatum Center|url = https://legatum.mit.edu/|access-date = 2016-02-14}}</ref> and the MIT Regional Entrepreneurship Acceleration Program (MIT REAP).<ref>{{Cite web|title = MIT Regional Entrepreneurship Acceleration Program|url = http://reap.mit.edu/|access-date = 2018-10-30}}</ref>
MIT GSW is an annual conference that brings together entrepreneurs, students, investors, and key stakeholders from across the world to accelerate the entrepreneurial ecosystem of a host region. Through a series of tailored workshops, panels and keynote speakers, MIT GSW aims to share the entrepreneurial practices that have empowered thousands of companies to launch from MIT.
Each year, about 30 MIT students, alumni, and staff organize the conference in close collaboration with partners from a different host country, tailoring the conference to the local cultural needs of the startup ecosystem in the country. Since 1998, the organization has held 21 international workshops across 6 continents.
The 21st edition of MIT GSW was held in [[Bangkok]], Thailand from 26–28 March 2018 in collaboration with [[Sasin Graduate Institute of Business Administration of Chulalongkorn University|Sasin School of Management]] and the MIT Association of Thailand.
== History == The MIT Global Startup Workshop (MIT GSW) was founded in 1997 when the MIT $50K (now the [[MIT $100K Entrepreneurship Competition|MIT $100K]]) Entrepreneurship Competition received numerous queries from around the world from organizations interested in starting and improving their own business plan competitions (BPCs). The first MIT GSW was held in Cambridge, Massachusetts in March 1998. A decade later, in 2007 the MIT GSW expanded its mission to include all aspects of the entrepreneurial ecosystem. Since its founding, the MIT GSW has held 21 international workshops across 6 continents, reached participants from over 70 nations, and grown to become the premier workshop for fostering global entrepreneurship.<ref name=":0">{{cite web|title=Join Leading Entrepreneurs at the MIT Global Startup Workshop|url=https://alum.mit.edu/slice/join-leading-entrepreneurs-mit-global-startup-workshop-march-28-30|website=SLICE of MIT|publisher=Massachusetts Institute of Technology|accessdate=16 February 2016}}</ref>
* 2018: [[Bangkok]], [[Thailand]] <ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.sasin.edu/mit-gsw-2018-recap/|website=Sasin Graduate Institute of Business Administration of Chulalongkorn University|title=MIT GSW 2018 Recap|access-date = 2018-11-12}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.sasin.edu/mit-global-startup-workshop-2018/|website=Sasin Graduate Institute of Business Administration of Chulalongkorn University|title=MIT - Global Startup Workshop 2018|access-date = 2018-11-12}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://gsw.mit.edu/2018/|title=MIT GSW 2018 Website|access-date = 2018-11-12}}</ref> * 2017: [[Santiago]], [[Chile]] * 2016 : [[Hyderabad]], [[India]] <ref>{{Cite web|title = Hyderabad to host MIT start-up workshop|url = http://www.thehindubusinessline.com/news/national/mitgsw-to-organise-annual-conference-in-hyderabad/article7924023.ece|website = The Hindu Business Line|access-date = 2016-02-14|first = M|last = Somasekhar}}</ref> * 2015 : [[Guatemala City]], [[Guatemala]] <ref>{{Cite web|url=http://gsw.mit.edu/2015/|title=MIT GSW 2015 Website|access-date = 2018-11-12}}</ref> * 2014 : [[Marrakech]], [[Morocco]] <ref>{{Cite web|url=http://gsw.mit.edu/2014/|title=MIT GSW 2014 Website|access-date = 2018-11-12}}</ref> * 2013 : [[Tallinn]], [[Estonia]] <ref>{{Cite web|url=http://gsw.mit.edu/2013/|title=MIT GSW 2013 Website|access-date = 2018-11-12}}</ref> * 2012 : [[Istanbul]], [[Turkey]] <ref>{{Cite web|url=http://gsw.mit.edu/2012/|title=MIT GSW 2012 Website|access-date = 2018-11-12}}</ref> * 2011 : [[Seoul]], [[Republic of Korea]] <ref>{{cite web|title=MIT Global Startup Workshop in South Korea|url=http://www.elon.edu/e-net/Article/54529|website=Elon University|publisher=Elon University|accessdate=14 February 2016}}</ref> <ref>{{Cite web|url=http://gsw.mit.edu/2011/|title=MIT GSW 2011 Website|access-date = 2018-11-12}}</ref> * 2010 : [[Reykjavik]], [[Iceland]] <ref>{{cite web|title=Íslandsbanki endorses the MIT Global Startup Workshop 2010|url=https://www.islandsbanki.is/english/about-islandsbanki/news/news-item/2010/03/19/Islandsbanki-endorses-the-MIT-Global-Startup-Workshop-2010/|website=Íslandsbanki|publisher=Íslandsbanki|accessdate=16 February 2016}}</ref> <ref>{{Cite web|url=http://gsw.mit.edu/2010/|title=MIT GSW 2010 Website|access-date = 2018-11-12}}</ref> * 2009 : [[Cape Town]], [[South Africa]] * 2008 : [[Madrid]], [[Spain]] * 2007 : [[Trondheim]], [[Norway]] * 2006 : [[Buenos Aires]], [[Argentina]]
== Featured past speakers == * [[Olafur Ragnar Grimsson]], President Of Iceland * [[Toomas Hendrik Ilves]], President Of The Republic Of Estonia * Hwang Chang-Gyu, National CTO Of South Korea * [[Dean Kamen]], Inventor Of [[Segway Inc.|Segway]] * [[Robin Chase]], Founder Of [[Zipcar]] * [[Krisztina 'Z' Holly]], Founder Of The First Tedx * [[Bill Aulet]], Managing Director Of the MIT Martin Trust Center * [[Gururaj Deshpande|Desh Desphande]], Founder Of MIT Deshpande Center for Innovation * Ariya Banomyong, Managing Director of [[Line (software)|LINE]] Thailand * Pita Limjaroenrat, Executive Director, [[Grab (company)|Grab]] Thailand
==Structure of the conference== MIT GSW platform facilitates conversations via panels and keynotes at the interface of * Entrepreneurship *Government Policy *Social and Development issues *Corporate responsibility *Startup culture and ecosystem MIT GSW is also a platform for extensive coaching for participants through a Business Plan Competition, Elevator Pitch Competition, and active mentoring for startups.<ref name=":0" />
==MIT GSW Competitions== MIT GSW offers multiple competitions of different scales and topical interests each year. Historically, GSW has included competitions, like the Elevator Pitch Competition, a Business Plan Competition, and a Startup Showcase, to shed light on innovative ventures and projects in the region of interest. Mentorship, scale, themes, and prizes vary in each edition of the conference.
==See also== * [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology]] * [[Martin Trust Center for MIT Entrepreneurship]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
== External links == * [http://gsw.mit.edu Official Website - MIT Global Startup] * [https://www.catalyzer.co/ Catalyzer - Hosting Partner MITGSW 2016]<ref>{{Cite web|title = India|url = http://2016.mitgsw.org/india#catalyzer|website = MIT GSW 2016|access-date = 2016-02-16}}</ref>

revision.text:
[[Image:Michail Melas.jpg|thumb|right|200px|Portrait of Melas on his election as Mayor of Athens]] '''Mihail Melas''' ({{lang-el|Μιχαήλ Μελάς}}, 1833–1897) was a [[Greece|Greek]] politician and merchant, who served as [[Mayor of Athens]] in 1891–1894.
==Biography== He was born in [[Syros]], the son of Georgios Melas, a member of the ''[[Filiki Eteria]]'' and the scion of a distinguished [[Epirote]] family. He studied law in [[Paris]] and became involved with commerce at an early age, importing Russian wheat to [[London]] and [[Marseilles]]. From these activities he amassed a large fortune.
In 1874, Melas settled permanently in [[Athens]], where he soon achieved a distinguished place among Athenian high society. He played a crucial role in the foundation of the Athens Club in 1875, the Greek capital's oldest and most exclusive [[gentlemen's club]], and served as its president in 1882–1886 and 1888–1897. In 1890, he was elected to the [[Greek Parliament]] for [[Attica]]. He became mayor of Athens in 1891, holding the office until 1894, after an unsuccessful first attempt in 1883, when he lost to [[Dimitrios Soutsos]]. Melas also served in the founding board of the [[Hellenic Red Cross]], and as chairman of the ''[[Ethniki Etaireia]]'', a secret nationalist society, which played a major role in the outbreak of the disastrous [[Greco-Turkish War of 1897]]. Melas is also notable as one of the first Athenians to build a house in [[Kifissia]], then a suburban summer resort for the capital's wealthy families. He was also an avid art collector, and during his stay in Marseilles, he chaired the local French Cultural Club for several years. In 1886–88 he served as president of the ''[[Filekpaideftiki Etaireia]]'' ("Learned Society", a charitable educational society founded in 1836).
== Family == He was married with Eleni Voutsina and had seven children: Maria, wife of Ektoras Romanos, chamberlain of [[Prince Nicholas of Greece]]; [[Anna Mela-Papadopoulou|Anna]], wife of the landowner Apostolos Papadopoulos; Georgios (1866–1931) a judge and private secretary of King [[Constantine I of Greece|Constantine I]]; [[Pavlos Melas|Pavlos]] (1870–1904), an [[Hellenic Army|Army]] officer and hero of the [[Macedonian Struggle]]; [[Leon M. Melas|Leon]] (1872–1905), a lawyer and politician; [[Konstantinos Melas]] (1874–1953), a [[Hellenic Navy|Navy]] officer and politician; and [[Vassileios M. Melas|Vassilios]] (1879–1956), a General and also president of the Athens Club.
{{S-start}} {{Succession box | before = [[Timoleon Filimon]] | title = [[Mayor of Athens]] | years = 1891–1894 | after = [[Dimitrios Silyvriotis]] }} {{end}} {{Mayors of Athens}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Melas, Michail}} [[Category:1833 births]] [[Category:1897 deaths]] [[Category:Mayors of Athens]] [[Category:Greek MPs 1890–92]] [[Category:People from Syros]] [[Category:Greek businesspeople]]

{{refimprove|date=February 2017}} {{Infobox company <!-- Commented out: | logo = File:Microsoft Dynamics Logo.png -->| logo_size = 200px | homepage = {{url|http://www.microsoft.com/erp}} }} '''Microsoft Dynamics ERP''' is [[enterprise resource planning]] (ERP) software primarily geared toward midsize organizations as well as subsidiaries and divisions of larger organizations. Its applications are part of [[Microsoft Dynamics]], a line of business management software owned and developed by [[Microsoft]].
Microsoft Dynamics ERP comprises five primary products: [[Axapta|Microsoft Dynamics AX]], [[Great Plains Software|Microsoft Dynamics GP]], [[Navision|Microsoft Dynamics NAV]], [[Solomon IV|Microsoft Dynamics SL]] and [[Microsoft Dynamics C5]].
==Products== Microsoft Dynamics ERP includes five primary products: *[[Microsoft Dynamics AX]] (formerly Axapta) is designed to help organizations do business across locations and countries by standardizing processes and helping to simplify compliance. The latest version is Microsoft Dynamics AX 2012 R3 CU8.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://www.queueassoc.com/solution/what-is-erp-crm/|title=What is Microsoft Dynamics ERP & CRM?|website=Queue}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.microsoft.com/en-in/dynamics/erp-ax-overview.aspx|title=Microsoft's ERP solution|website=Microsoft}}</ref> *[[Microsoft Dynamics GP]]<ref name=":0" /> (formerly Great Plains Software) can help companies adapt to new opportunities and growth by managing changing markets, enabling unique business requirements, and connecting business processes across the organization. The latest version is Microsoft Dynamics GP 2018. *[[Microsoft Dynamics NAV]] (formerly Navision) is designed to help organizations streamline specialized and industry-specific business processes. The latest version is Microsoft Dynamics NAV 2018.<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=http://www.erpsoftwareblog.com/category/about-microsoft-dynamics-nav/}}</ref> *[[Microsoft Dynamics SL]] (formerly Solomon IV) can help project-driven organizations obtain reports and business analysis and automate projects across company divisions and locations. The latest version is Microsoft Dynamics SL 2015.<ref name=":1" /> *[[Microsoft Dynamics C5]] (formerly Concorde C5) can assist with finance, manufacturing, supply chains, analytics and electronic commerce for small and medium-sized enterprises. The latest version is Microsoft Dynamics C5 2012.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://global.eg.dk/competencies/erp-systems/microsoft-dynamics-c5|title=Microsoft Dynamics C5|website=EG}}</ref>
==Capabilities== Microsoft Dynamics ERP applications are designed to help customers: * Manage the entire supply chain. * Make current financial data and reports accessible for business planning and regulatory compliance. * Automate repetitious and routine functions so that employees can focus on more critical tasks. * Minimize the cost and complexity of administering salaries, benefits, recruiting, and performance management. * Provide greater visibility into key performance factors, such as profitability and potential issues. * Meet industry-specific needs with functionality for vertical business processes.
Microsoft Dynamics ERP has five focus industries: *[[Financial services|Financial Services]] *[[Manufacturing]] *[[Public sector|Public Sector]] *[[Retail]] *[[Tertiary sector of the economy|Service Industry]]
==See also== *[[List of ERP software packages]] *[[Microsoft Dynamics CRM]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
== External links == * {{official website|http://www.microsoft.com/en-us/dynamics/erp.aspx}}

{{Infobox person |name = Nizan Guanaes |image = Nizan_Guanaes.jpg |alt = Nizan Guanaes, participated in the Global Citizen 2017 event, where the speaker was Barack Obama 44th President of the United States of America, in São Paulo (SP) - Brazil |caption = Nizan Guanaes, participated in the Global Citizen 2017 event, where the speaker was Barack Obama 44th President of the United States of America, in São Paulo (SP) - Brazil |birth_date = {{birth date and age|1958|05|09}} |birth_place = [[Salvador, Bahia]] |nationality = Brazilian |occupation = Co-founder and partner of Grupo ABC - ABC Group |spouse = Donata Meirelles }}
'''Nizan Mansur de Carvalho Guanaes Gomes''' (born May 9, 1958 in [[Salvador, Bahia|Salvador]]) is a Brazilian advertising executive.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://adage.com/article/special-report-influencers-2010/marketing-brazil-s-nizan-guanaes-grupo-abc/147932/|title=Nizan Guanaes, Grupo ABC|author=Lauren Wentz|date=3 January 2011|publisher=AdAge|language=portuguese|accessdate=19 March 2015}}</ref><ref name="Colunas Revista Época">{{cite web|url=http://epocanegocios.globo.com/Revista/Common/0,,ERT235603-16373,00.html|title=Nizan e Eike, mais criativos|publisher=Colunas Revista Época|language=portuguese|accessdate=19 March 2015}}</ref>
He is a co-founder and partner of [[ABC Group]], a holding company that comprises 18 companies with operations ranging from [[advertising]] and [[marketing]] to content and entertainment.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://adage.com/article/special-report-agency-alist-2014/africa-ad-age-s-2014-international-agency-year/291339/|title=International Agency of the year|author=Lauren Wentz|date=3 February 2014|publisher=AdAge|language=Portuguese|accessdate=19 March 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://exame.abril.com.br/negocios/noticias/livro-conta-como-nizan-guanaes-ergueu-o-grupo-abc|title=Como Nizan ergueu grupo ABC|author=Luísa Melo|date=18 August 2014|publisher=Exame|language=Portuguese|accessdate=19 March 2015}}</ref><ref name="FinancialTimes">{{cite web|url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/2d842cd4-b6f5-11e0-a8b8-00144feabdc0.html#axzz3Rx8ri200|title=Nizan Guanaes, grupo ABC|publisher=FinancialTimes|language=Portuguese|accessdate=19 March 2015}}</ref><ref name="The Wall Street Journal">{{cite web|url=https://blogs.wsj.com/dailyfix/2014/07/08/germany-set-to-be-confronted-by-thousands-of-neymars/|title=Germany confronted by thousands of neymars|author=Luciana Magalhaes|date=8 July 2014|publisher=The Wall Street Journal|language=Portuguese|accessdate=19 March 2015}}</ref> ABC Group is the largest communications holding company in Latin America and the 18th largest communications group in the world, according to Advertising Age.<ref name="GQ">{{cite web|url=http://gq.globo.com/Men-of-the-Year/noticia/2014/11/men-year-premia-nizan-guanaes-na-categoria-lideranca.html|title=Men of the year Nizan Guanaes| author=Guilherme Manechini|date=28 November 2014|publisher=GQ|language=Portuguese|accessdate=19 March 2015}}</ref><ref name="Valor Econômico">{{cite web|url=http://www.valor.com.br/empresas/2641706/grupo-abc-sobe-em-ranking-mundial-de-publicidade|title=Grupo ABC sobe em ranking| author=Adriana Mattos|date=2 May 2012|publisher=Valor Econômico|language=Portuguese|accessdate=19 March 2015}}</ref>
Nizan was voted one of the five most influential Brazilians by [[Financial Times]] in 2010; one of the world’s 100 most creative people by [[Fast Company (magazine)|Fast Company]] in 2011 and in 2014, Man of The Year, in Leadership’s category by [[GQ]].<ref name="GQ"/><ref name="Valor Econômico">{{cite web|url=http://www.valor.com.br/empresas/2641706/grupo-abc-sobe-em-ranking-mundial-de-publicidade|title=Grupo ABC sobe em ranking| author=Adriana Mattos|date=2 May 2012|publisher=Valor Econômico|language=Portuguese|accessdate=19 March 2015}}</ref>
==Biography== Nizan Guanaes was born in 1958, in [[Salvador, Bahia]]. He studied at Colégio Marista and graduated from [[Universidade Federal da Bahia]] with a degree in business administration. He began his career as a [[copywriter]] in his home city. Years later, he moved to [[Rio de Janeiro]] and worked at Artplan, a Brazilian advertising agency. When he moved to [[São Paulo]] in 1985, he built a reputation as a skilled advertising copywriter at DPZ and W/GGK, nowadays W/McCann.<ref name="Exame Abril">{{cite web|url=http://exame.abril.com.br/negocios/noticias/livro-conta-como-nizan-guanaes-ergueu-o-grupo-abc|title=Como Nizan Guanaes ergueu grupo ABC|author=Marcelo Spatafora|date=18 August 2014|publisher=Exame Abril|language=Portuguese|accessdate=19 March 2015}}</ref><ref name="Época Negócios">{{cite web|url=http://epocanegocios.globo.com/Informacao/Visao/noticia/2012/12/nizan-guanaes.html|title=Nizan Guanaes|author=Nelson Blecher|date=30 March 2013|publisher=Época Negócios|language=Portuguese|accessdate=19 March 2015}}</ref>
In 1988, he won the Gold Lion award at [[Cannes Festival]] for the memorable television advertisement “Hitler,” created for the newspaper [[Folha de São Paulo|Folha de S.Paulo]] – considered one of the 100 best advertisements of all time.<ref name="Época Negócios"/><ref name="PubliStorm">{{cite web|url=http://www.publistorm.com/na-estante-comercial-hitler-da-folha-de-sao-paulo/|title=Comercial Hitler|author=Felipe Agnello Ceranto|date=16 May 2010|publisher=PubliStorm|language=Portuguese|accessdate=19 March 2015}}</ref> In the next year, he bought and took over DM9, advertising agency of Duda Mendonça. The agency was associated with DDB, becoming DM9DDB in 1997. In 2000, DM9 was acquired by DDB Worldwide.<ref name="Exame Abril">{{cite web|url=http://exame.abril.com.br/negocios/noticias/livro-conta-como-nizan-guanaes-ergueu-o-grupo-abc|title=Como Nizan Guanaes ergueu grupo ABC|author=Marcelo Spatafora|date=18 August 2014|publisher=Exame Abril|language=Portuguese|accessdate=19 March 2015}}</ref><ref name="Palestrantes">{{cite web|url=http://www.palestrantes.org/palestrante.asp?id=40|title=Nizan Guanaes|publisher=Palestrantes|language=Portuguese|accessdate=19 March 2015}}</ref>
In the same year, Guanaes founded internet portal iG, the second largest free internet portal in Brazil.<ref name="Época Negócios"/> Two years later, in 2002, Nizan created ABC Group with business partner João Augusto (Guga) Valente with Icatu Group as an investor.<ref name="Exame Abril">{{cite web|url=http://exame.abril.com.br/negocios/noticias/livro-conta-como-nizan-guanaes-ergueu-o-grupo-abc|title=Como Nizan Guanaes ergueu grupo ABC|author=Marcelo Spatafora|date=18 August 2014|publisher=Exame Abril|language=Portuguese|accessdate=19 March 2015}}</ref>
In 2004, with Oskar Metsavaht, he founded the Association of Entrepreneurs Friends of [[UNESCO]] focusing to promote quality public education, culture and conserve the national historical heritage.<ref name="Época">{{cite web|url=http://epocanegocios.globo.com/Revista/Common/0,,ERT235603-16373,00.html|title=Nizan e Eike, os mais criativos|publisher=Época|language=Portuguese|accessdate=19 March 2015}}</ref><ref name="Unesco">{{cite web|url=http://www.unesco.org/new/pt/brasilia/about-this-office/single-view/news/brazilians_nizan_guanaes_oskar_metsavaht_and_vik_muniz_named_unesco_goodwill_ambassadors-1/#.VOF4jC685mg|title=Nizan sera nomeado embaixador UNESCO|date=23 May 2011|publisher=Unesco|language=portuguese|accessdate=19 March 2015}}</ref>
Since 2010, Nizan is a member in high level commission of UNAIDS, a program from [[United Nations]] (UN) that creates and debates solutions to prevent HIV.<ref name="Isaude">{{cite web|url=http://www.isaude.net/pt-BR/noticia/9364/geral/unaids-lanca-comissao-de-lideres-mundiais-para-prevencao-da-aids|title=Líderes prevenção da AIDS|date=22 July 2010|publisher=Isaude|language=Portuguese|accessdate=19 March 2015}}</ref>
Nizan is also a member of following non-profitable foundations: [[Clinton Global Initiative]], created by [[Bill Clinton]], with the stated mission to "strengthen the capacity of people to meet the challenges of global interdependence"; World Economic Forum, based in Switzerland and committed to engage leaders of society to shape global agendas, including health and environment; Endeavor, that identify valuable entrepreneurs to world’s sustainable growth; and Women in the World Foundation, that helps non-governmental organization (NGOs) offer solutions to build a better life for women and girls.<ref name="Propmark Mercado">{{cite web|url=http://propmark.uol.com.br/mercado/26752:nizan-guanaes-apresenta-rio-summer-2008/|title=Nizan Guanaes apresenta Rio Summer|date=5 August 2008|publisher=Propmark Mercado|language=Portuguese|accessdate=19 March 2015}}</ref><ref name="WEForum">{{cite web|url=http://www.weforum.org/contributors/nizan-guanaes|title=Nizan Guanaes|publisher=WEForum|language=Portuguese|accessdate=19 March 2015}}</ref><ref name="Propmark Global">{{cite web|url=http://propmark.uol.com.br/mercado/6829:abc-lanca-brazilian-global-leaders|title=ABC lança Brazilian global leaders|date= 25 September 2011|publisher=Propmark Global|language=Portuguese|accessdate=19 March 2015}}</ref><ref name="IG">{{cite web|url=http://www.vivimascaro.com.br/gossip/post/?2933/nizan_guanaes_participa_do_clinton_global_initiative_em_ny.htm|title=Nizan Guanaes no Clinton Global Initiative|date= 24 September 2014|publisher=IG|language=Portuguese|accessdate=19 March 2015}}</ref> Nizan also contributed to create, in 2011, the Together for Girls,” a project developed to identify and combat sexual violence against girls and its social effects.<ref name="Propmark Global"/>
Nizan writes in Folha de S.Paulo on Tuesdays, every 14 days, on “Market” session.<ref name="Folha Coluna">{{cite web|url=http://www1.folha.uol.com.br/colunas/nizanguanaes/|title=Nizan Guanaes|publisher=Folha Coluna|language=Portuguese|accessdate=19 March 2015}}</ref>
===Founder of ABC Group=== ABC Group was founded by Nizan Guanaes and Guga Valente in March, 2002. The holding company comprises 18 companies such as Africa, DM9DDB, DM9 Rio, DM9 Sul, Escala, Loducca, Morya, Música Comunicação e Marketing, Pereira & O’Dell, b!ferraz, Interbrand, NewStyle, Rocker Heads, Sunset, Agência Tudo and CDN.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://exame.abril.com.br/negocios/noticias/nizan-guanaes-compra-cdn-e-estreia-em-relacoes-publicas|title=Nizan Guanaes compra CDN|author=Márcio Juliboli|date=17 August 2013|publisher=Exame|language=Portuguese|accessdate=19 March 2015}}</ref><ref name="Adnews">{{cite web|url=http://www.adnews.com.br/cristal-festival/nizan-guanaes-sera-homenagedo-no-cristal-festival|title=Nizan Guanaes homenageado no Cristal Festival|date=5 November 2014|publisher=Adnews|language=Portuguese|accessdate=19 March 2015}}</ref>
In the same year, Nizan founded Africa, middle marketing agency with four partners of DDB Brazil and Icatu Bank. In 2015, Africa is considered one of the ten largest advertising agencies in Brazil.<ref name="Propaganda Matéria">{{cite web|url=http://www.revistapropaganda.com.br/materia.aspx?m=595|title=Grupo ABC: o ano da consolidação|date=5 December 2010 |publisher=Propaganda Matéria|language=Portuguese|accessdate=19 March 2015}}</ref>
==Recognition== In 2000, Nizan Guanaes received a gold medal in Rio Branco Order given by Brazilian ex-president, [[Fernando Henrique Cardoso]]. The Rio Branco Order is a commendation that awards important services and civic virtues in Brazil.<ref name="Itamaraty">{{cite web|url=http://www.itamaraty.gov.br/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=5698:ordem-de-rio-branco&catid=222:cerimonial&Itemid=450&lang=pt-br|title=Ordem de Rio Branco|publisher=Itamaraty|language=Portuguese|accessdate=19 March 2015}}</ref>
Nizan was voted the Entrepreneur of the Year in Ernst & Young Brazil in 2008.<ref name="Revista Crescer">{{cite web|url=http://revistacrescer.globo.com/Revista/Crescer/0,,ERT22790-15565,00.html|title=Nizan ganha Prêmio Empreendedor do ano|publisher=Revista Crescer|language=Portuguese|accessdate=19 March 2015}}</ref> Later that year, through one of his companies, the N-Idéias, he was the mastermind of Rio Summer, a high-summer fashion week.<ref name="Propmark">{{cite web|url=http://propmark.uol.com.br/mercado/26752:nizan-guanaes-apresenta-rio-summer-2008/|title=Nizan apresenta Rio Summer 2008|date=5 August 2008|publisher=Propmark|language=Portuguese|accessdate=19 March 2015}}</ref>
In 2009, he was chosen the Communication Entrepreneur of the Year by [[Revista IstoÉ]].
In 2010, he was voted one of the five most influential Brazilians by [[Financial Times]].<ref name="FT">{{cite web|url=http://www.ft.com/intl/cms/s/0/cc7a2456-7d17-11df-8845-00144feabdc0.html#axzz3RsKYMqzj|title=Five influential Brazilians|author=Jonathan Wheatley and Vincent Bevins|date=28 June 2010|publisher=FT|language=Portuguese|accessdate=19 March 2015}}</ref>
In the next year, he was nominated one of the most influential professionals in media and marketing by Advertising Age, an American magazine considered one of the most respectful in advertising field.<ref name="JCR UOL">{{cite web|url=http://jcrs.uol.com.br/acontecendo/adage-elege-nizan-guanaes-um-dos-21-mais-influentes-na-area-de-midia/|title=Adage elege Nizan Guanaes|date=7 January 2011|publisher=JCR UOL|language=Portuguese|accessdate=19 March 2015}}</ref>
Also in 2011, he was voted one of the world’s 100 most creative people by Fast Company, an American magazine of business and technology.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://epocanegocios.globo.com/Revista/Common/0,,ERT235603-16373,00.html|title=Nizan e Eike, mais criativos|publisher=Época Negócios|language=Portuguese|accessdate=19 March 2015}}</ref> He was also Ambassador of Good Will by United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization (UNESCO), when they recognized his support to vulnerable groups in education and social inclusion.<ref name="Folha">{{cite web|url=http://www1.folha.uol.com.br/fsp/mercado/me3105201123.htm|title=O que nos torna humanos|publisher=Folha|language=Portuguese|accessdate=19 March 2015}}</ref>
In 2013, was indicated by Exame magazine as one of the sixteen Brazilians entrepreneurs convicted to make history, as a businessman and creative advertiser.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://exame.abril.com.br/negocios/noticias/nizan-guanaes-compra-cdn-e-estreia-em-relacoes-publicas|title=Nizan Guanaes compra CDN|author=Márcio Juliboni|date=17 August 2013|publisher=Exame|language=Portuguese|accessdate=19 March 2015}}</ref>
In 2014, he was the Man of The Year, in Leadership’s category by GQ, an American magazine focused on men’s lifestyle.<ref name="GQ"/> In the same year he was voted for the third time the most trustworthy advertiser, according to the 13th Research of Reliable Brands, by Seleções magazine and the Brazilian Institute of Public Opinion and Statistics (IBOPE).<ref name="Adnews"/><ref name="UOL">{{cite web|url=http://propmark.uol.com.br/mercado/49149:revista-selecoes-atualiza-profissionais-e-marcas-de-confianca|title=Profissionais e marcas de confiança|author=Vinícuis Novaes|date=28 July 2014|publisher=UOL|language=Portuguese|accessdate=19 March 2015}}</ref>
In December 2014, he won the Jeca Tatu award at 9th Copywriters Encounter, which awards the Best professionals of Brazilian advertising.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.adnews.com.br/negocios/nizan-guanaes-recebe-premio-jeca-tatu-na-proxima-terca|title=Nizan recebe prêmio Jeca Tatu|date=27 November 2014|publisher=Adnews Negócios|language=Portuguese|accessdate=19 March 2015}}</ref>
<gallery> File:Nizan no Clinton Global Initiative.JPG|Clinton Global Initiative (CGI) - September 24, 2009 File:Rio Patrimonio da Humanidade.jpg|Support to social causes in Rio de Janeiro - October 24, 2008 </gallery>
==Personal life== Nizan Guanaes has one son, Antonio Guanaes. He is married with [[Donata Meirelles]], fashion director at [[Vogue (magazine)|Vogue]] Brazil.<ref name="Casa Vogue">{{cite web|url=http://revista.casavogue.globo.com/interiores/a-casa-de-donata-meirelles-e-nizan-guanaes-no-rio/|title=A casa de Donata Meirelles e Nizan Guanaes|date=19 December 2011|publisher=Casa Vogue|language=Portuguese|accessdate=19 March 2015}}</ref>

{{About|the business term|the computing term|Overhead (computing)}}
[[File:Money Cash.jpg|thumb|400x400px|Overheads and direct costs, when combined, equals total expenses endured by a business.]] In business, '''overhead''' or '''overhead expense''' refers to an ongoing [[expense]] of operating a business. Overheads are the [[expenditure]] which cannot be conveniently traced to or identified with any particular cost unit, unlike operating expenses such as raw material and labor. Therefore, overheads cannot be immediately associated with the products or services being offered, thus do not directly generate profits.<ref>{{Cite web |title= PMO and Project Management Dictionary - PM Hut |url= http://www.pmhut.com/pmo-and-project-management-dictionary|website = www.pmhut.com |accessdate= 2015-10-26}}</ref> However, overheads are still vital to business operations as they provide critical support for the business to carry out profit making activities.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|title = What is overhead? - Questions & Answers - AccountingTools|url = http://www.accountingtools.com/questions-and-answers/what-is-overhead.html|website = www.accountingtools.com|accessdate = 2015-10-26}}</ref> For example, overhead costs such as the rent for a factory allows workers to manufacture products which can then be sold for a profit. Such expenses are incurred for output generally and not for particular work order; e.g., wages paid to watch and ward staff, heating and lighting expenses of factory, etc. Overheads are also very important cost element along with direct materials and direct labor.<ref name=":0" />
Overheads are often related to [[accounting]] concepts such as [[fixed cost]]s and [[indirect costs]].
Overhead expenses are all costs on the income statement except for direct labor, direct materials, and direct expenses. Overhead expenses include accounting fees, [[advertising]], [[insurance]], interest, legal fees, labor burden, [[renting|rent]], repairs, supplies, taxes, telephone bills, travel expenditures, and [[utilities]].<ref>{{Cite web|title = Calculating overhead and price {{!}} Missouri Business Development Program|url = http://missouribusiness.net/article/calculating-overhead-and-price/|website = missouribusiness.net|accessdate = 2015-10-26}}</ref>
There are essentially two types of business overheads: administrative overheads and manufacturing overheads.<ref>{{Cite book|title = The Effects of Lean Manufacturing|last = Cook ; Graser|first = Cynthia ; John|publisher = RAND Corporation|year = 2001|isbn = |location = |pages = 103}}</ref>
== Administrative overheads == Administrative overheads include items such as utilities, strategic planning, and various supporting functions. These costs are treated as overheads due to the fact that they aren't directly related to any particular function of the organization nor does it directly result in generating any [[profit (accounting)|profit]]s. Instead, these costs simply take on the role of supporting all of the business' other functions.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Administrative Costs and Overhead|url = http://www.huffingtonpost.com/paul-brest/administrative-costs-and_b_162505.html|website = The Huffington Post|accessdate = 2015-10-26}}</ref>
Universities regularly charge administrative overhead rates on research. In the U.S. the average overhead rate is 52%, which is spent on building operation, administrative salaries and other areas not directly tied to research.<ref>Tracy Jan. Research giants win on federal funding: Fend off US bid to cut overhead payments. Boston Globe. March 18, 2013. https://www.bostonglobe.com/news/nation/2013/03/17/harvard-mit-and-other-research-schools-thwart-obama-administration-effort-cap-overhead-payments/Nk5PT0Mc8MQZihFVNs5gNK/story.html</ref> Academics have argued against these charges. For example, [[Benjamin Ginsberg (political scientist)|Benjamin Ginsberg]] showed how overhead rates are primarily used to subsidize ballooning administrative salaries and building depreciation, neither of which directly benefit research; although it does benefit the administrators that determine university policy in his book [[The Fall of Faculty]]. An article written by [[Joshua Pearce]] in [[Science (journal)|Science]] argued that overhead accounting practices hurt science by removing funds from research and discouraging the use of less-expensive [[open source hardware]].<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Pearce | first1 = Joshua M. | year = 2016 | title = Undermined by overhead accounting | url = http://science.sciencemag.org/content/352/6282/158.2 | journal = Science | volume = 352 | issue = | pages = 158–159 | doi = 10.1126/science.352.6282.158-b }}</ref> He went into detail on the accounting showing how millions were wasted each year on overhead cash grabs by university administrators in [[ZME Science]].<ref>[http://www.zmescience.com/science/antiquated-accounting-costs-millions/ How Antiquated Accounting Costs American Science Millions a Year]. ''ZME Science'' 3.9.2016.</ref>
=== Examples ===
==== Employee salaries ==== This includes mainly monthly and annual [[Salary|salaries]] that are agreed upon. They are considered overheads as these costs must be paid regardless of sales and profits of the company. In addition, salary differs from wage as salary is not affected by working hours and time, therefore will remain constant.<ref>{{Cite journal|jstor = 1883513|title = Fixed Costs and Market Price|last = Bell|first = Spurgeon|date = 1918|journal = The Quarterly Journal of Economics|doi = 10.2307/1883513|pmid = |volume=32|pages=507}}</ref> In particular, this would more commonly apply to more senior staff members as they are typically signed to longer tenure contracts, meaning that their salaries are more commonly predetermined.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Are Wages Paid to Temporary Personnel a Variable Cost?|url = http://smallbusiness.chron.com/wages-paid-temporary-personnel-variable-cost-38573.html|website = Small Business - Chron.com|accessdate = 2015-10-26}}</ref>
==== Office equipment and supplies ==== This includes office equipment such as printer, fax machine, computers, refrigerator, etc. They are equipment that do not directly result in sales and profits as they are only used for supporting functions that they can provide to [[business operations]].<ref>{{Cite web|title = Fixed Costs: Definition, Formula & Examples - Video & Lesson Transcript {{!}} Study.com|url = http://study.com/academy/lesson/fixed-costs-definition-formula-examples.html|website = Study.com|accessdate = 2015-10-26}}</ref> However, equipment can vary between administrative overheads and manufacturing overheads based on the purpose of which they are using the equipment. For example, for a printing company a printer would be considered a manufacturing overhead.<ref>{{Cite journal|jstor = 2391742|title = Research on the Size of Administrative Overhead and Productivity: Some Methodological Considerations|last = Dogramaci|first = Ali|date = March 1977|journal = Administrative Science Quarterly|doi = 10.2307/2391742|pmid = |volume=22|pages=22}}</ref>
==== External legal and audit fees ==== This includes the cost of hiring external law and [[audit]] firms on behalf of the company. This would not apply if company has own internal lawyers and audit plans. Due to [[regulation]]s and necessary annual audits to ensure a satisfactory work place environment, these costs often cannot be avoided. Also, since these costs do not necessarily contribute directly to sales, they are considered as indirect overheads. Although in most cases necessary, these costs can sometimes be avoided and reduced.<ref>{{Cite journal|jstor = 2549364|title = Fixed Costs|last = Lewis|first = Arthur W.|date = Nov 1946|journal = Economica|doi = 10.2307/2549364|pmid = |volume=13|pages=231}}</ref>
==== Company cars ==== Many companies provide usage of company cars as a [[Employee benefit|perk]] for their employees. Since these cars do not contribute directly to sales and profits, they are considered an overhead. Similar company perks that are a one-off or constant payment such as partner [[contract]] fees with a gym will also fall under administrative overheads.<ref>{{Cite book|title = Putting a Price Tag on Perks: Valuing employee benefits|last = BARRETT JR.|first = JOHN E.|publisher = American Bar Association|year = 2001|isbn = |location = |pages = 26}}</ref>
==== Travel and entertainment costs ==== This will include company-paid business travels and arrangements. As well as refreshments, meals, and entertainment fees during company gatherings. Although one might argue that these costs motivate workers to become more productive and efficient, the majority of economists agree that these costs do not directly contribute to sales and profits, therefore shall be categorized as an administrative overhead.<ref>{{Cite journal|jstor = 10.1086/587761|title = A Rent Extraction View of Employee Discounts and Benefits|last = Marino ; Zábojník|first = Anthony M. ; Ján|date = July 2008|journal = Journal of Labor Economics|doi = 10.1086/587761|pmid = |volume=26|pages=485–518}}</ref> Despite these costs occurring periodically and sometimes without prior preparation, they are usually one-off payments and are expected to be within the company's [[budget]] for travel and entertainment.<ref>{{Cite journal|jstor = 30189250|title = The Ultimate Management Perk|last = Mackiel|first = John J.|date = Dec 1996|journal = The Clearing House|doi = 10.1080/00098655.1996.9959406|pmid = |volume=70|pages=95–96}}</ref>
== Manufacturing overheads == Manufacturing overheads are all costs endured by a business that is within the physical platform in which the product or service is created. Difference between manufacturing overheads and administrative overheads is that manufacturing overheads are categorized within a [[factory]] or office in which the sale takes place.<ref>{{Cite journal|url = http://astro.temple.edu/~banker/Accounting/15%20An%20Empirical%20Study%20of%20Manufacturing%20Overhead%20Cost%20Drivers.pdf|title = An empirical analysis of manufacturing overhead cost drivers|last = Banker ; Potter ; Schroeder|first = Rajiv ; Gordon ; Roger G.|date = July 1994|journal = Journal of Accounting and Economics|doi = 10.1016/0165-4101(94)00372-c|pmid = |access-date = 2015-11-01|volume=19|pages=115–137}}</ref> Whilst administrative overheads is typically categorized within some sort of [[Back office|back-office]] or supporting office. Although there are cases when the two physical buildings may overlap, it is the usage of the overheads that separates them.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Chapter 46 Overhead Variances|url = http://www.unf.edu/~dtanner/dtch/dt_ch46.htm|website = www.unf.edu|accessdate = 2015-11-01}}</ref>
=== Examples ===
==== Employee salaries ==== Although the general concept is identical to the example under administrative overheads, the key difference is the role of the employee. In the case of manufacturing overheads, employees would have roles such as [[Maintenance, repair, and operations|maintenance]] personnel, manufacturing [[managers]], materials management staff, and [[quality control]] staff. It would also include the set [[wage]]s for janitorial staff members. Once again, the key difference lies in the nature of their respective jobs and the physical location in which their jobs are carried out.<ref>{{Cite journal|url = http://journals.cambridge.org/action/displayAbstract?fromPage=online&aid=8329411&fileId=S0007680500028932|title = Early Cost Accounting for Internal Management Control|last = Johnson|first = Thomas H.|date = 11 June 2012|journal = Business History Review|doi = 10.2307/3113343|pmid = |access-date = 2015-11-01|volume=46|pages=466–474}}</ref>
==== Depreciation of assets and equipment ==== This refers to the reduction in [[value (economics)|value]] of equipments as it becomes older and more obsolete. For example, if a printer has a potential useful life span of 5 years, the amount that it can be sold for will decrease each year.<ref>{{Cite book|title = Cost Management with a Strategic Emphasis|last = Blocher ; Berry|first = Edward ; William|publisher = Ohio State University Press|year = 1998|isbn = |location = Columbus, Ohio|pages = }}</ref> Therefore, this value in [[depreciation]] is calculated as a manufacturing overhead. Moreover, this also applies to vehicles as they tend to depreciate in value significantly after the first year. When calculating manufacturing overheads, [[accountant]]s mainly use two [[Accounting method|method]]<nowiki/>s: straight-line method and declining balance method.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.gnucash.org/docs/v2.6/C/gnucash-guide/dep_value1.html|title = Estimating Valuation|date = |accessdate = 2015-11-01|website = GnuCash|publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref><nowiki/>
==== Property Taxes on Production Facilities ==== Every single [[property]] unless government owned is subject to some form of [[property tax]].<ref>{{Cite web|title = Capitalization Period of Direct and Indirect Costs|url = https://www.irs.gov/Businesses/Small-Businesses-&-Self-Employed/Capitalization-Period-of-Direct-and-Indirect-Costs|website = www.irs.gov|accessdate = 2015-11-01}}</ref> Therefore, the [[tax]]es on production factories are categorized as manufacturing overheads as they are costs which cannot be avoided nor cancelled. In addition, property taxes do not change in relation to the business's profits or sales and will likely remain the same unless a change by the [[government administration]].<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Indirect Costs|journal = Science|date = 1981-09-11|pages = 1198–1203|volume = 213|series = New Series|issue = 4513|first = Lionel F.|last = Jaffe|first2 = Herbert|last2 = Gursky|first3 = Samuel B.|last3 = Guze|first4 = John W.|last4 = Donahoe|first5 = Kenneth T.|last5 = Brown|doi=10.1126/science.213.4513.1198-b|jstor=1687322}}</ref> [[File:The central gate factory «OCM».JPG|thumb|The rent for factory buildings is considered a manufacturing overhead]]
==== Rent of Factory Building ==== Unless the business decides to purchase land and build its own factory, it will be subject to some sort of [[renting|rent]] due to the amount of [[Capital accumulation|capital]] required to build a privately owned factory. Therefore, this rent must be paid to the landlord on a regular basis regardless of the performance of the business. Although the rent for the building provides the physical platform for the company to produce its products and services, it is not a direct contributor.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Fixed Costs, Efficient Resource Management, and Conservation|journal = American Journal of Agricultural Economics|date = 2001-11-01|pages = 942–957|volume = 83|issue = 4|first = Jinhua|last = Zhao|first2 = David|last2 = Zilberman|doi=10.1111/0002-9092.00221|jstor=1244705}}</ref>
==== Utilities for Factory ==== This would vary depending on how the [[utility bill]] is structured. In the case of it being an overhead, the utility bill is pre-negotiated meaning that the monthly utility bill will be the same regardless of the amount in which the factory actually consumes.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Electric Utilities--Costs and Performance|journal = Journal of Political Economy|date = 1962-08-01|pages = 406–407|volume = 70|issue = 4|first = Yoram|last = Barzel|doi=10.1086/258672|jstor=1861741}}</ref> This will only be relevant in various countries where there is an option for standardized utility bills. However, due to the vast consumption of electricity, gas, and water in most factories, most companies tend to not have standardized utility bills as it tends to be more expensive.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://eit.umd.edu/~nsw/chbe446/HowToEstimateUtilityCosts-UlrichVasudevan2006.pdf|title = How to Estimate Utility Costs|date = April 2006|accessdate = 2015-11-01|website = |publisher = University of New Hampshire Press|last = Ulrich ; Vasudevan|first = Gael D. ; Palligarnai T.}}</ref> Standardized utility bills are also oftentimes discouraged by governments as it leads to wastage of resources and [[Externalities|negative externalities of production]].<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://eml.berkeley.edu/~saez/course131/externalities1_ch05.pdf|title = Externalities: Problems and Solutions|date = |accessdate = 2015-11-01|website = 131 Undergraduate Public Economics|publisher = University of California Berkeley Press|last = Saez|first = Emmanuel}}</ref>
== Application of Business Overheads == For most businesses, business overheads are calculated by [[accountant]]s for [[budget]]ing purposes but also often so the business has an idea of how much they must charge consumers in order to make a [[Profit (economics)|profit]]. The following are common accounting tools which take account of business overheads.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.leanconstruction.org/media/docs/IGLC02Kim-Ballard.pdf|title = OVERHEAD COSTS ANALYSIS|date = August 2002|accessdate = 2015-11-02|website = |publisher = University of Berkeley Press|last = Kim ; Ballard|first = Yong-Woo ; Glenn}}</ref> [[File:CVP-FC-Contrib-PL-BEP.svg|thumb|A standard break-even analysis chart]]
=== Break-Even Analysis === The [[Break even analysis|break-even analysis]] determines the point which the business's revenue is equivalent to the costs required to receive that revenue. It first calculates a [[Margin of safety (accounting)|margin of safety]] (the point which the revenue exceeds the break-even point) as that is the "safe" amount which the revenue can fall whilst still remaining to be above the break-even point.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Break-Even Analysis Definition {{!}} Investopedia|url = http://www.investopedia.com/terms/b/breakevenanalysis.asp?optm=sa_v2|website = Investopedia|accessdate = 2015-11-02|language = en-US}}</ref> The graph on the right shows a typical break-even chart. [[Contribution margin|Contribution]] refers to sales of the product or service, it can also be interpreted as the business's [[revenue]] stream. Fixed costs in this case serves the same purpose as business overheads, it will simply be shown as a straight horizontal line on the graph as shown.<ref>{{Cite web|title = An HBR Refresher on Breakeven Quantity|url = https://hbr.org/2015/06/an-hbr-refresher-on-breakeven-quantity|website = Harvard Business Review|accessdate = 2015-11-02}}</ref>
=== Shut-Down Graph === In economics, revenue curves are often illustrated to show whether or not a business should stay in business, or shut down. In theory, if a business is able cover variable [[operational costs]] but unable to cover business overheads in the short run, the business should remain in business. On the other hand, if the business is not even able to cover [[operational costs]], it should shut down.<ref>{{Cite web |url= http://people.oregonstate.edu/~emersonp/201/notes/12.pdf |title= Economics 201 Lecture 12 |date= |accessdate= 2015-11-02 |website= people.oregonstate.edu |publisher= Oregon State University |last= |first= }}</ref> Although this rule largely differs depending on the size of the business, the business's cash-flow, and the [[Competition (economics)|competitive]] nature of the business, it serves as a model rule for most small competitive businesses to operate on.<ref>{{Cite book|title = Microeconomics|last = Perloff|first = J.|publisher = Pearson|year = 2009|isbn = 0-321-56439-1|location = |pages = 237}}</ref>
=== Balance Sheet === [[Balance sheet]] is a financial statement which outlines a company's [[financial asset]]s, [[LIABILITIES|liabilities]], and [[Shareholder's Equity|shareholder's equity]] at a specific time. Both assets and liabilities are separated into two categories depending on their time frame; current and long-term. Business overheads in particular fall under current liabilities as they are costs for which the company must pay on a relatively short-term/immediate basis. Although the balance sheet by itself does not offer much information, it is a useful piece of financial information when combined with other documents such as the [[income statement]] or [[ratio analysis]] as it offers a diverse and well-rounded description of the company's financial position.<ref>{{Cite web|title = The Balance Sheet: What Does It Mean? CDFS-1154|url = http://ohioline.osu.edu/cd-fact/1154.html|website = ohioline.osu.edu|accessdate = 2015-11-02}}</ref>
==See also== *[[Operating expense]] *[[Expense ratio]]

{{EngvarB|date=September 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2014}} {{dablink|This article is about the British businessman. For the American businessman , see [[Richard Baker (US businessman)|Richard Baker]]}} {{other people|Richard Baker}}
{{Infobox person |name = Richard Baker |image = |caption = |birth_date = {{Birth date and age|df=yes|1962|8|6}} |birth_place = |death_date = |death_place = |nationality =British |residence = Stamford, Lincolnshire, United Kingdom |occupation = chairman of European Division of [[Groupe Aeroplan]] |salary = |networth = |spouse = |website = |footnotes = |children = |religion = }}'''Richard Baker''' (born 6 August 1962) is the former chief operating officer of [[Asda|Asda Stores Ltd.]]<ref>Richard Baker worked as director at ASDA Group Limited from 1 November 1999 to 15 September 2003 – source: http://www.cbetta.com/director/richard-baker-31</ref> and CEO of [[Boots Group]]. He is currently chairman of the European Division of [[Groupe Aeroplan]], which owns and runs the [[Nectar loyalty card|Nectar Loyalty Programme]] in the UK. He also serves as non-executive chairman of [[Virgin Active]], non-executive director of [[Whitbread plc]], operating partner at [[Advent International]] and chairman of [[DFS (United Kingdom retailer)|DFS]].
==Biography== After graduating from [[Downing College, Cambridge|Downing College]], [[University of Cambridge|Cambridge]], Baker worked at [[Mars Confectionery]] for nearly 10 years, working his way up to sales and marketing director.<ref>{{citation | title = How the Martians took over UK retail | work = The Observer | date = 4 May 2003 | url = https://www.theguardian.com/business/2003/may/04/theobserver.observerbusiness13 | accessdate = 27 January 2010 | location=London | first=Sarah | last=Ryle}}</ref><ref>{{citation | title = Baker makes tough decisions as he seeks catalyst for high street chemist's renewal | work = Sunday Herald | date = 4 September 2005 | url = http://www.heraldscotland.com/sport/spl/aberdeen/baker-makes-tough-decisions-as-he-seeks-catalyst-for-high-street-chemist-s-renewal-a-let-go-to-grow-policy-drives-richard-baker-s-plans-for-an-old-high-street-favourite-finds-ken-symon-first-person-1.43948 | accessdate = 27 January 2010}}</ref> He joined [[Asda|Asda Stores Ltd]] in 1995,<ref>{{citation | title = Boots shops at Asda for new chief executive | work = The Independent | date = 1 May 2003 | accessdate = 27 January 2010 | url = https://www.independent.co.uk/news/business/news/boots-shops-at-asda-for-new-chief-executive-542502.html | location=London | first=Nigel | last=Cope}}</ref> where he worked for the following 9 years becoming Marketing Director in 1999,<ref>{{citation | title = How the Wal-Mart deal will boost Asda | work = Marketing Week | url = http://www.marketingweek.co.uk/home/how-the-wal-mart-deal-will-boost-asda/2036852.article | date = 17 June 1999 | accessdate = 27 January 2010}}</ref> and ultimately chief operating officer in 2002, following their acquisition by [[Walmart]].<ref>{{citation | title = DeNunzio takes reins at Asda | work = Mass Market Retailers | date = 21 October 2002 | url = http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_hb3235/is_15_19/ai_n28954651/ | accessdate = 27 January 2010}}</ref>
In September 2003, Baker joined [[Boots Group]] as chief executive officer.<ref>{{citation | title = Chemist's chain greets new chief with a £1.6m hello | work = The Independent | date = 2 May 2003 | url = https://www.independent.co.uk/news/business/news/chemists-chain-greets-new-chief-with-acircpound16m-hello-537854.html | accessdate = 27 January 2010 | location=London | first=Nigel | last=Cope}}</ref> The company had been reporting losses following its ill-advised move into its 'Wellbeing' services, which included [[Dentistry]], [[Massage]] and [[Botox]].<ref>{{citation | title = Wellbeing proves a little too painful for Boots | work = Evening Standard | date = 27 March 2003 | url = http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-99268667.html | accessdate = 27 January 2010}}</ref><ref>{{citation | title = Boots to cut 700 jobs from Wellbeing stores | work = The Telegraph | url = https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/1425781/Boots-to-cut-700-jobs-from-Wellbeing-stores.html | date = 27 March 2003 | accessdate = 27 January 2010 | location=London}}</ref> Despite implementing a number of cost-cutting measures and extending opening hours, the company continued to struggle until October 2005 it announced it was to merge with competitor [[Alliance Unichem]].<ref>{{citation | title = Shareholders blast Boots over merger | work = The Telegraph | url = https://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/2923212/Shareholders-blast-Boots-over-merger.html | date = 3 October 2005 | accessdate = 27 January 2010 | location=London | first1=Kate | last1=Rankine}}</ref> The announcement met with widespread opposition, but the merger was cleared by the OFT in February 2006 and completed in July that year.<ref>{{citation | title = Boots to get green light on £7bn Alliance deal | work = The Independent | date = 2 July 2006 | url = https://www.independent.co.uk/news/business/news/boots-to-get-green-light-on-1637bn-alliance-deal-406270.html | accessdate = 27 January 2010 | location=London | first=Abigail | last=Townsend}}</ref><ref>{{citation | title = UK's largest pharmacy created as Boots completes merger | work = The Telegraph | date = 31 July 2006 | url = https://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/2944492/UKs-largest-pharmacy-created-as-Boots-completes-merger.html | accessdate = 27 January 2010 | location=London | first=Caroline | last=Muspratt}}</ref> Baker became chief executive officer of the new [[Alliance Boots|Alliance Boots GmbH]].<ref>{{citation | title = Profile: Richard Baker, chief executive of Alliance Boots | work = The Telegraph | date = 5 May 2007 | url = https://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/2808402/Profile-Richard-Baker-chief-executive-of-Alliance-Boots.html | accessdate = 27 January 2010 | location=London | first1=Richard | last1=Fletcher}}</ref>
In April 2007, after publishing annual results that showed a profit increase of 7.4%, Alliance Boots was sold to [[private equity]] firm [[Kohlberg Kravis Roberts|KKR]] for £11.1 billion; the highest price ever paid by a private equity company for a British public company.<ref>{{citation | title = Equity Firm Wins Bidding for a Retailer, Alliance Boots | work = New York Times | date = 25 April 2007 | url = https://www.nytimes.com/2007/04/25/business/worldbusiness/25boots.html?_r=1 | accessdate = 27 January 2010 | first=Julia | last=Werdigier}}</ref><ref>{{citation | title = Battle lines drawn for top job at Alliance Boots | work = The Times | date = 2 May 2007 | url = http://business.timesonline.co.uk/tol/business/industry_sectors/retailing/article1735127.ece | accessdate = 27 January 2010 | location=London | first=Dearbail | last=Jordan}}</ref> Baker left the company on completion of the transaction.<ref>{{citation | title = Alliance Boots chief quits post | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/business/6291846.stm | work = BBC News | date = 11 July 2007 | accessdate = 27 January 2010}}</ref> Baker has served as chairman of [[DFS (United Kingdom retailer)|DFS]] since April 2010, following [[Advent International]]'s £500 million takeover of the furniture retail chain.<ref name=DFS>{{citation | title = 'Categorically not for sale' DFS goes for £500m | url = http://business.timesonline.co.uk/tol/business/industry_sectors/retailing/article7104705.ece | work = The Times | date = 23 April 2010 | accessdate = 13 September 2010 | first=Marcus | last=Leroux}}</ref>
==Current roles==
Baker now holds various board and advisory roles with top international companies including:
* Chairman of the European Division of [[Groupe Aeroplan]], which owns and runs the [[Nectar loyalty card|Nectar Loyalty Programme]] in the UK. It also has interests in other loyalty schemes across Europe.<ref>{{citation | title = Nectar card owner names ex Boots head Richard Baker to board | work = Marketing Magazine | date = 27 February 2009 | url = http://www.marketingmagazine.co.uk/news/884350/Nectar-card-owner-names-ex-Boots-head-Richard-Baker-board/ | accessdate = 27 January 2010}}</ref><ref>{{citation | title = Richard Baker to chair Nectar company advisory board | work = Marketing Week | date = 26 February 2009 | url = http://www.marketingweek.co.uk/news/richard-baker-to-chair-nectar-company-advisory-board/2064467.article | accessdate = 27 January 2010}}</ref> * Non Executive Chairman of [[Virgin Active]].<ref>{{citation | title = Virgin Active could get new boss | work = The Telegraph | date = 28 April 2008 | url = https://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/markets/2789082/Virgin-Active-could-get-new-boss.html | accessdate = 27 January 2010 | location=London | first=Edmund | last=Conway}}</ref> * non executive director of [[Whitbread plc]].<ref>{{citation | title = Richard Baker accepts Whitbread's offer to return to City | work = The Telegraph | date = 5 September 2009 | url = https://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/newsbysector/retailandconsumer/6143253/Richard-Baker-accepts-Whitbreads-offer-to-return-to-City.html | accessdate = 27 January 2010 | location=London | first1=Jonathan | last1=Sibun | first2=Jonathan | last2=Russell}}</ref><ref>{{citation | title = Whitbread hires ex-Boots boss as sales slide | work = The Times | date = 7 September 2009 | url = http://business.timesonline.co.uk/tol/business/industry_sectors/leisure/article6824359.ece?print=yes&randnum=1151003209000 | accessdate = 27 January 2010 | location=London | first=Robert | last=Lindsay}}</ref> * Operating Partner at [[Advent International]].<ref>{{citation | title = Former Boots boss Richard Baker joins private equity firm Advent | work = Retail Week | date = 20 August 2009 | url = http://www.retail-week.com/careers/appointments/former-boots-boss-baker-joins-private-equity-firm-advent/5005501.article | accessdate = 27 January 2010}}</ref> * Chairman of [[DFS (United Kingdom retailer)|DFS]].<ref name=DFS/>

{{Infobox building |name = Riverplace Tower |former_names = Gulf Life Tower |image = Riverplace Tower in Jacksonville.jpg |image_size = 200px |caption = |building_type = Commercial offices |architectural_style= [[Mid-century modern]] |location = 1301 Riverplace Boulevard [[Jacksonville, Florida|Jacksonville]], [[Florida]], [[United States]] |coordinates = {{coord|30.319403|-81.656541|region:US-FL_source:kolossus-dewiki|display=inline,title}} |map_type = United States Jacksonville#USA Florida |start_date = 1966 |completion_date = 1967 |opening = 1967 |floor_area = {{convert|542000|sqft|m2|-1|abbr=on}}< |antenna_spire = |roof = {{convert|432|ft|m|abbr=on}}{{cite web|url=http://www.emporis.com/buildings/118934/riverplace-tower-jacksonville-fl-usa |title=Riverplace Tower |accessdate=2016-05-16 |publisher=Emporis.com}} |elevator_count = 8 |floor_count = 28 |architect = [[Welton Becket]] |architecture_firm = [[KBJ Architects]] |developer = Capital Partners |owner = [[Lingerfelt CommonWealth Partners]] }} The '''Riverplace Tower''' is a 28-floor office building on the south bank of the [[St. Johns River]] in [[Jacksonville, Florida]]. At the time of its construction, it was the tallest building in the state of Florida and was the defining landmark in Jacksonville's skyline.[http://skyscraperpage.com/cities/?buildingID=119 "Riverplace Tower"] Skyscraper Page website, Database On April 18, 2012, the [[American Institute of Architects]]'s Florida Chapter placed the building on its list of ''Florida Architecture: 100 Years. 100 Places'' as the '''Riverplace Tower / Formerly Gulf Life Tower'''.[http://www.aiaflatop100.org/Current-Standings.cfm Florida Architecture: 100 Years. 100 Places] ==History== [[Image:GulfLifeJAX.jpg|thumb|left|250px|Gulf Life Tower in 1968.]] The Auchter Company, Jacksonville's oldest general construction contractor, built the 542,000 ft2 '''Gulf Life Tower''' for the Gulf Life Insurance Company in 1966. It was designed by the notable architect, [[Welton Becket]] and [[KBJ Architects]]. When completed in 1967, it was the tallest precast, post-tensioned concrete structure in the world.[http://direct.bl.uk/bld/PlaceOrder.do?UIN=158149873&ETOC=RN&from=searchengine British Library Direct: Concrete Products 2004, VOL 107; NUMB 10, pages 52-52] It remained Florida's tallest for five years until Miami's [[One Biscayne Tower]] was constructed in 1972. It was Jacksonville's tallest for eight years until the [[Independent Life Building]] (now the Wells Fargo Center) was built in 1974. In 2007, 40 years after its construction, Riverplace Tower was still the fifth tallest building in Jacksonville. Gulf Life Insurance Company was merged into American General Life of Houston in 1991 and the Jacksonville Gulf Life Tower was unneeded and destined to be sold.[http://www.aig.com/American-General-Life-Accident_20_21374.html AIG website: Company history] American General wanted $30 million, but the building was 24 years old and no longer a class "A" property. Several prospective buyers looked at the building, but the property stayed on the market for more than two years. For tax reasons, American General was desperate to sell during 1993 and accepted a cash offer from [[Gate Petroleum]] for substantially less than their asking price. Shortly thereafter, Gate began a multimillion-dollar renovation of the entire building and renamed it ''Riverplace Tower''.Peyton, H: "Newboy", page 159. Edwards Brothers, 1997 Building occupancy was 40% when the sale closed; within two years from the completion of the renovation, it had soared to nearly 95% and the building was restored to its former prominence.Brune-Mathis, Karen: [http://jacksonville.com/tu-online/stories/090397/1b4barne.html "Barnett's buildings in question"] Florida Times-Union, September 3, 1997 The banner sign at the top of the building originally displayed "Gulf Life" in 1967. After Gulf Life was acquired by American General in 1991, it was changed to "SouthTrust", and the structure was known as the ''SouthTrust Building''. When SouthTrust and Wachovia merged in 2005, "Wachovia" signage was installed, but it was removed January 22, 2011.Fletcher, Jon M.: [http://jacksonville.com/video/news/metro/2011-01-23/watch-wachovia-signage-removed-riverplace-tower "Watch: Wachovia Signage Removed from Riverplace Tower"] Florida Times-Union, January 23, 2011 Since 1968, the University Club of Jacksonville has occupied the building's top floor. The private club is available members and their guests, or [[ClubCorp]] affiliates. There are approximately 1,300 members: business executives of both genders; older, long-term associates; and young professionals. The facility is a hub for networking and entertaining clients, as well as providing conference rooms and offices for conducting business in private. The club also offers two full service athletic facilities; one co-ed and one for men only.Capullo, Lori: [http://www.floridatrend.com/article.asp?aID=55522 "Private Business Clubs in Florida"] Florida Trend magazine, September 1, 2011[http://www.virtualtourist.com/travel/North_America/United_States_of_America/Florida/Jacksonville-763031/Local_Customs-Jacksonville-Skyscrapers_Architecture-BR-1.html Virtual tourist.com: Skyscrapers & Architecture: Riverplace Tower and its little known dining spots] ==Description and tenants== The structural system consists of precast concrete floorplates and a poured concrete core. The concrete grid on the outside of the building is the only support needed to hold up the structure, leaving the interior completely available for use. Each of the exposed beams consist of fourteen precast units held together with high strength post-tensioned steel cables. The beams cantilever 42 feet from the columns as they taper upward and inward. The color of the concrete façade comes from White quartz sand and white cement bonded to the surface.[http://www.emporis.com/en/wm/bu/?id=riverplacetower-jacksonville-fl-usa Emporis.com] The [[Gate River Run]] ''Hall of Fame'' was established in 2002 and is permanently located on the concourse level. Memorabilia from the event, which began in 1978, is on display, and a five-minute video gives visitors an overview of the race. Plaques for each of the 12 persons inducted into the HOF are on display.[http://www.gate-riverrun.com/hof.htm "Hall of Fame"] Gate River Run website The Southbank Grille is a public restaurant located on the second floor of the tower, and it offers an excellent view of the river and northbank through its glass, north-facing wall. ==Honors== In honor of its 50th anniversary, the ''Precast/Prestressed Concrete Institute'' went through the arduous process of selecting the Seven precast concrete "Wonders". Their choices were: the Department of Housing & Urban Development Headquarters in Washington, D.C.; '''Gulf Life Tower in Jacksonville, Fla.;''' Disney World Monorail in Orlando, Fla.; TransAmerica Pyramid in San Francisco, Calif.; Aurora Justice Facility and Municipal Center in Aurora, Colo.; Sunshine Skyway Bridge in Tampa Bay, Fla.; and the Blue Cross-Blue Shield Parking Structure in North Haven, Conn.[http://www.pci.org/publications/newsletters/etrends/issue_23.cfm Precast Concrete Institute publications: Issue 23] According to an Architecture article in ''Time Magazine'', "(the) Gulf Life, placed in a shoddy, chaotic part of Jacksonville, is a tonic for its area, acts as an organizing beacon. And the bold Alcoa building…makes a positive contribution to San Francisco. Both buildings thus achieve excellence." [http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,838498-4,00.html Time Magazine: Aug. 02, 1968- To Cherish Rather than Destroy] ==Gallery== File:Jacksonville, FL, Riverplace Tower from Crown Plaza Hotel, Apr 2012.jpg| File:Jacksonville Riverplace Tower and The Peninsula Digon3.jpg| File:Southbank, Jacksonville, FL 32207, USA - panoramio (1).jpg| File:Southbank, Jacksonville, FL 32207, USA - panoramio (2).jpg| File:Riverplaceameris.jpg| ==See also== * [[Architecture of Jacksonville]] * [[List of tallest buildings in Jacksonville]] * [[Downtown Jacksonville]] ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} {{s-start}} {{s-ach|rec}} {{succession box |before=[[Aetna Building]] |title=[[List of tallest buildings in Jacksonville|Tallest Building in Jacksonville]] |years=1967—1974
132m |after=[[Wells Fargo Center (Jacksonville)|Wells Fargo Center]]}} {{s-end}} ==External links== {{Commons category}} * [http://www.gateriverplace.com/ Riverplace Official website] * [http://www.clubcorp.com/club/scripts/section/section.asp?NS=PCH&SUBGRP=15&MFCODE=UCJAX University Club website] {{Jacksonville attractions}} [[Category:Ameris Bancorp]] [[Category:KBJ Architects buildings]] [[Category:Skyscraper office buildings in Jacksonville, Florida]] [[Category:Welton Becket buildings]] [[Category:Modernist architecture in Florida]] [[Category:Downtown Jacksonville]] [[Category:Southbank, Jacksonville]] [[Category:Jacksonville Modern architecture]] [[Category:Architecture in Jacksonville, Florida]] [[Category:Office buildings completed in 1967]] [[Category:1967 establishments in Florida]]
